item.title: Money Pit Stop: If I invest the profits from my business and buy-to-let, can I retire before I'm 50?
item.description: Kevin, 36, wants to invest rental income and money from his business in a growth portfolio, with the goal of having enough money to retire when he is aged between 45 and 50.
item.content:encoded:
In our series Money Pit Stop, we ask an investing expert to give one of our readers a free portfolio makeover.

Kevin, 36, lives in Bristol and is a self-employed mechanical engineer, with an expanding firm specialising in business development consultancy work. He and his wife Demelza, 35, have a baby daughter Siena, aged one.

They own one property they are renting out, are in the process of buying a second property to rent out, and have a 50 per cent stake in a third property that is also rented out. They live rent-free themselves in a separate property.

Kevin wants to invest rental income and money from his business in a growth portfolio, with the goal of having enough money to retire when he is aged between 45 and 50. He wants to invest £15,000 to start off with, but plans to invest at least £1,000 - more if he can - every month for the next 10 years.

Kevin would also like to know if he should invest solely in his own name, or whether there would be advantages - tax or otherwise - to creating a second investment account for his daughter, and diverting some money into that.

Investment goals: 'To achieve financial freedom for myself and my wife and retire early. To be able to build a fund for my daughter for her future.'

FIND OUT HOW TO GET YOUR FREE PORTFOLIO MAKEOVER BELOW 

KEVIN'S SAVINGS AND INVESTMENTS 

Risk appetite: Medium to high risk. Kevin says: 'At the moment I feel that I am still young enough to take some calculated risks.'

Shares, funds, trusts and ETFs: None

Savings: £15,000

Property and mortgages: Flat, mortgage £202,000, value £400,000

Flat, in process of purchasing, no mortgage, value £56,000

House, 50 per cent share, no mortgage, value £140,000

Wayne Berry is an investment manager at wealth manager Brewin Dolphin. He says:

Kevin and his wife have a portfolio of properties which seems to have worked well for them over the years.

Using the rental income from the properties as well as regular savings from the income from Kevin’s consultancy business to diversify their assets is a sensible move.

In terms of income from potential investments and capital growth, I don’t believe any great deal of tax planning needs to be done.

The initial investment of £15,000 fits comfortably within Kevin’s annual Isa subscription allowance of £20,000. The Isa wrapper then prevents capital gains and income from being taxable.

The regular contributions of £1,000 per month (£12,000 per tax year) would also fall into the Isa allowance comfortably.

More consideration may need to be given to inheritance tax further down the line. 

At the moment, it shouldn’t be an issue as the net assets for Kevin and Demelza would be covered by the £325,000 nil rate bands each of them receive for inheritance tax.

10 WAYS TO AVOID INHERITANCE TAX LEGALLY

 Read a This is Money guide on how to prevent loved ones getting lumped with a hefty inheritance tax bill unnecessarily. 

However, in terms of making provisions for their daughter, regular contributions to a Junior Isa would be sensible.

This would allow Kevin and Demelza to contribute £4,128 per annum into an Isa for Siena and would benefit from the same Isa benefits in terms of growth and income being tax free.

Siena will then be entitled to the Isa portfolio when she reaches the age of 18. 

Whilst Kevin has not mentioned anything regarding pension provision, depending on how successful his consultancy is, this is an area to consider as the tax benefits of investing can be very attractive, especially for a higher rate tax payer, although the funds cannot be accessed until age 55. 

Whilst pensions are considered 'dull', it provides you with the potential to plan for income tax and inheritance tax, as personal pensions can be passed onto beneficiaries in a much more tax efficient manner following the freedoms set out by former Chancellor George Osborne.

WHAT ARE THE TAX BENEFITS OF PENSIONS? 

Pension tax relief is aimed at encouraging us all to save more for retirement, but at present you get a bigger sweetener the more you earn.

The rebate we get is based on our income tax rates of 20 per cent, 40 per cent or 45 per cent, which tilts the system in favour of the better-off.

But it's supposed to ensure you aren't penalised by tax on your pension contributions, so if you earn enough to put more in your pot you get more back in tax relief. The current rules are rumoured to be under review by the Government ahead of the Budget on 22 November.

Meanwhile, the rules on inheriting retirement pots were relaxed in April 2015, including the abolition of a hated 55 per cent death tax on pension income drawdown plans left to relatives. This is Money 

Given their relative young ages, the portfolio for Kevin, his wife and daughter can afford to have more exposure to equities with a view to reducing this in the future, especially as they come towards wanting to retire.

If I were Kevin, I would invest into a portfolio which is split roughly 42.5 per cent UK equities, 42.5 per cent overseas equities and the balance split between alternative investments, such as infrastructure, absolute return and specialist investments, such as private equity.

He already has direct exposure to residential property, but could consider some exposure to commercial property too.

In the UK equity element of the portfolio, I would look at investments in Old Mutual UK Mid Cap Fund, Man GLG UK Undervalued Assets and the Threadneedle UK Equity Income Fund, which complement one another quite nicely and provide exposure to all areas of the market and company sizes. See the sample portfolio and the asset breakdown below.

Overseas, I suggest a tracker in the US as well as investment trusts and unit trusts with a more global approach initially.

Holdings such as Scottish Mortgage Investment Trust and RIT Capital Partners fit the bill quite nicely for global exposure. These investments are not restricted in terms of geography and provide exposure to most equity markets as well as unlisted shares.

Whilst the portfolio will be initiated with a lump sum of £15,000, the regular contributions will be beneficial as they allow for pound cost averaging.

WHAT IS POUND COST AVERAGING? 

This is jargon for regularly drip feeding your money into financial markets. Investors are generally advised to do this once a month, rather than risking a lump sum at what might turn out to be a bad time.

It also forces you to buy even during market bloodbaths when stocks are cheap, not just during rallies when they are expensive. This is Money

Although equity markets appear to be reasonably high at the moment, investing on a regular basis will help smooth out some of the volatility over a 10-year time horizon.

True, there will be times when you are investing when equity markets appear expensive, but you will also benefit from investing in times of market distress which will, quite literally, pay dividends over a long period.

One should remember the investing adage: 'It’s time in the market, not timing the market'.

In conclusion, I would say that Kevin’s investment goal of achieving financial freedom and retiring early would all depend on the type of lifestyle he was looking to achieve in retirement.

Given Kevin’s current savings appetite, combined with his mortgage commitment and desire to also have a savings fund for his daughter, I would say that his retirement income is likely to be fairly modest, unless he is able to put aside more than he plans to at present.

If we take a retirement age of 50 for Kevin, and if he saves the minimum £1,000 per month for the next 14 years (from age 36 to 50), and given a compound return of 4.5 per cent per year in 'real terms' (after inflation), Kevin would have around £250,000 at retirement. His retirement nest egg would drop to £170,000 if he retires at 46.

By retiring early, Kevin and Demelza will probably have to make their savings stretch over many decades. Many people under-estimate how long they are likely to live.

As for the options at the point of retirement, purchasing an annuity with the sums cited above and at those ages would produce a very small guaranteed income.

In all likelihood, Kevin and Demelza would want to stay invested and draw down an income from their savings during their retirement years, rather than pull all their money out of the markets at that stage, which is also something to bear in mind.

SAMPLE PORTFOLIO FROM BREWIN DOLPHIN
Holding  Weighting

item.title: I've got five WWF 50p coins that I've saved from my change, are they really worth much more?
item.description: I've received five WWF 50p coins over the years that I've held onto and I'm wondering if they are actually worth more than face value?
item.content:encoded:
I've received five WWF 50p coins over the years that I've held onto and I'm wondering if they are actually worth more than face value?

I don't want to spend them only to find that I could have sold them online for far more than a collective £2.50. C.M, via e-mail.

Lee Boyce, consumer affairs editor at This is Money, replies: We have been inundated by plucky collectors contacting us this year asking whether certain notes or coins are worth more than face value.

Many are collecting them as a sideline hobby, checking their change to see what designs they have – and whether anything unusual turns up.

Much of this has developed after our widely read round-up of rare coins that can turn up in your change.

It's safe to say 50p coins are among the most collected by Britons. For example, the Royal Mint issued Beatrix Potter themed ones last year, which were incredibly popular to add to collections.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • The valuable coins that can turn up in your change... and the red herrings to watch out for

The rarest 50p coin by some way is the one with the Kew Gardens pagoda stamped on it. 

Only 210,000 were minted in 2009 and they regularly sell online for £50 or more in good condition.

According to blog Change Checker, the next four rarest 50p coins are ones issued for the 2012 Olympics and minted in 2011.

These are, in order, the football themed one, followed by triathlon, judo and wrestling. Again, these can sell for tidy sums online.

In terms of mintage, the wrestling coin saw 1,129,500 made – the second lowest of all 50ps, but still far more than the Kew Gardens one. These sell for around £10-15 online.

The WWF coin was also minted in 2011. The coin depicts 50 animals – with the familiar WWF panda logo at the centre.

There were 3.4million of these coins minted, fairly low for a 50p. 

Only the Suffragettes design from 2003 (with a mintage of 3,124,030) and Jemima Puddle Duck from last year (2.1million) have a lower number, bar the Olympic coins and the Kew Gardens one.

It is likely that many have taken them out of circulation because of their love of nature and its quirky design.

On online marketplace eBay, there are 'buy it now' versions for the coin listed for around £2-2.50.

Some are selling for far more, but these are 'brilliant uncirculated' versions of the coin which are unlikely to turn up in your change.

It is relatively similar to the Benjamin Britten 50p coin we covered last year – a myth had developed that they were worth way more than face value.

However, 5.3million of them had been minted, making it far less scarce than many other 50p coins.

A quick search online shows other publications stating these WWF coins regularly sell for more than £200.

As with always in these coin stories, it is worth whatever someone is willing to pay.

People may be looking for this WWF coin for their collection, but I find it unlikely that many would pay more than a couple of quid - and that is roughly how much I can find examples online for, with plenty unsold. 

Do you have a coin you think may be valuable? Get in touch: lee.boyce@thisismoney.co.uk

item.title: I have bitcoin worth £4million that I bought five years ago for £5,000. Will I have to pay tax if I sell?
item.description: I'm a basic-rate taxpayer employed in IT and, by an amazing bit of luck, bought 1,000 bitcoins in 2012 for £5 each. As this is a virtual currency, do I have to declare the sale for tax purposes?
item.content:encoded:
I'm a basic-rate taxpayer employed in IT and, by an amazing bit of luck, bought 1,000 bitcoins in 2012 for £5 each. I've been told they are now worth more than £4 million at the current exchange rate.

As this is a virtual currency, does that mean I have to declare the sale for tax purposes? I've been told any gain is tax free because the money doesn't really exist in tangible form.

Geraint Jones, tax adviser at London and Cambridge accountancy firm BKL, replies: Virtual currencies, or cryptocurrencies as they are sometimes known, are becoming an increasingly popular way to transact.

As a result the value of some cryptocurrencies has risen beyond belief, and you are by no means unique in having become a bitcoin millionaire. 

However, cryptocurrencies do have tax implications of their own.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • What you need to know each week: Listen to the This is Money podcast

HMRC has not introduced any new legislation that relates specifically to cryptocurrencies as it believes that the existing legislation is sufficient to impose any necessary tax.

By far the most popular cryptocurrency is the bitcoin, however there are approximately 1,000 such currencies with others, such as ethereum and litecoins, becoming increasingly popular.

Individuals can obtain cryptocurrencies such as bitcoins in two ways. One is via 'mining', which is a system that allows computer users to calculate complex algorithms required to verify each transaction in the blockchain and be rewarded with bitcoins.

The second way is to use a bitcoin exchange to purchase bitcoins with a real world currency such a sterling.

If someone is mining bitcoins then HMRC regards this as a trade and will charge any profits to income tax and national insurance. Income and expenses would need to be calculated in sterling each year with the profits reported to HMRC and tax duly paid. Any expenses claimed would need to relate solely and specifically to the trade of mining.

If the bitcoins have been purchased HMRC will regard any increase in value as being liable to capital gains tax. Tax will only crystallise when the bitcoins are converted into another currency, be it sterling or dollars or even another cryptocurrency. Capital gains tax is currently charges at ten per cent or 20 per cent (or a mixture ) depending on the level of the taxpayer’s other income. 

Therefore in the situation above, the bitcoin seller is liable to capital gains tax on the gain arising. As the current price of a bitcoin is approximately £4,500 that would lead to a capital gain of £4,495,000 (£4,500,000 less £5,000) which after a capital gains tax exemption of £11,300 leaves a tax liability for a higher or additional rate taxpayer of £896,740.

Any tax liabilities relating to either mining or investing in virtual currencies which arose in the year to 5 April 2017 needs to be reported to HMRC with any tax paid by 31 January 2018. If the individual concerned does not have a filing reference an immediate application needs to be made on form SA1.

Sooner or later HMRC will catch up with cryptocurrency users who have made large gains because they will probably transfer the monies back into a traditional currency at some time.

Remember, just because cryptocurrencies are unregulated does not mean they are not taxable.

item.title: How much does my electric heater cost to run? I’ve started to turn it on and am worried about my energy bill
item.description: How much does our electric heater cost to run? It's getting chillier and it is time to turn it on but I'm worried I'm running up large energy bills by having one.
item.content:encoded:
How much does our electric heater cost to run? 

It's getting chillier and it is time to turn it on but I'm worried I'm running up large energy bills by having one.

Rebecca Rutt, of This is Money, replies: As autumn settles in, households across the country are starting to consider turning the heating on.

The cheapest way to heat your home is usually through a standard central heating system with a boiler and radiators. 

These systems use hot water which circulates through your pipes and connects to the radiators in the home.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you save hundreds by switching energy providers? Compare prices in your postcode

But some people choose to opt for an electric heater either instead of, or in addition to, central heating. 

These tend to be some of the most expensive ways to heat a home as they run on electricity rather than gas, which is more costly.   

If you have a standard variable tariff, it's likely your bills will have risen further this year and you will take a double hit.

This is because all of the Big Six suppliers have hiked prices, with most increasing the price of electricity by more than the price of gas, thanks in part to rising wholesale prices.

To work out exactly how much you can expect to pay, we checked the Energy Use Calculator.

If you had the heater on for an average of 90 minutes every day for a year (you are likely to have it on for longer in the winter, but not on at all in the summer) it would add an average of £175.22 onto your energy bills.

This calculation is worked out by taking an average 2kw electric heater, and the average price of a unit of energy from a Big Six provider, of 16p.

These two costs are then multiplied together for the figure of £0.4800 per day, £14.60 per month and £175.22 per year.

The price you pay specifically will depend on the power of your heater, the time you have it on for, and the amount you pay for electricity – which you can find on one of your energy statements. 

Alternatively if you have a smart meter you can easily see how much energy it is using by looking at the difference between your usage when the fan is on and then when it is switched off.

By 2020 all homes that want them will have smart meters, so fears about unexpectedly high bills after using more energy than usual will be a thing of the past.

To cut your bills, there are a few things you can do. Firstly, you could switch your energy supplier if you're not already on the cheapest tariff available to you.

You say your bills have increased this year which means you must be on a standard tariff. These are typically the most expensive available and therefore by switching to a fixed-rate tariff, whereby the price you pay for energy is set, you are likely to save. 

There may also be other changes which could help keep your home warmer for longer, and cutting down the time you need the electric heater to be on.

These include; extending your central heating system and radiators to all areas of your home, replacing older appliances with energy-efficient versions, making sure any gaps around your windows or under the door frame are filled to avoid cold air getting in, having your windows double glazed, or having insulation fitted.

While these changes may be expensive upfront, they’re likely to cut your bills in the long term and therefore may be worthwhile.

A new gas boiler, for example, will typically cost around £2,300 plus the cost of the radiators, but you could cut the cost of your heating bill by nearly half and save by around £560 a year, according to the EST.

There are also several schemes for getting free energy saving measures. Last month Eon announced a scheme for cavity wall and roof insulation while the Green Deal, which offers loans to pay for these measures, has also recently re-launched.

item.title: Let's get ethical: which saving and investment products allow you to do good and STILL make a healthy return?
item.description: As part of Good Money week, we take a look at the some of the 'ethical' financial products that promise to pay a decent return.
item.content:encoded:
With Good Money Week in full swing, we mark the ethical investment campaign with a look at the green opportunities that can make you a healthy return. 

Socially responsible investments have become more commonplace in the investment universe, thanks to an uptick in demand.

There has been an 11 per cent increase in assets under management in across 196 sustainable and ethical funds, rising by £10billion in the past four months to £96billion, according to investing firms Good With Money and 3D Investing.

There's now a plethora of investment opportunities under the 'ethical' banner to sift through. Here are some of the highly rated and newest products available.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Want a better return on your money? Get help with Timber's simple low-cost financial advice

Funds 

We asked Damien Lardoux, portfolio manager of boutique wealth manager at EQ Investors, to recommend three funds or trusts for impact investing.

This investment strategy puts focus on companies, organisations, and funds seeking to generate social and environmental impact through their products, services and business practices.

Here are his picks.

FP Wheb Sustainability Fund

The fund selects stocks that play into nine identified social and environmental themes, such as resource efficiency, sustainable transport, education or healthcare.

He credits the managers of the portfolio for actively seeking out companies providing positive solutions to various social and environmental issues while outperforming global equity funds over the past five years.

'What really differentiates this fund is the publication of an annual report where they detail absolute measure of positive environmental impact,' he says.

'For every £1million invested in the fund in 2016, 1,200 MWh of renewable energy was generated, equivalent to the total energy use of 60 average UK households. 

'Also 1,600 tonnes of CO2 emissions have been avoided, the equivalent to taking 333 cars off the road for a year.'

The fund has returned 68 per cent over the past five years to 11 October. 

Impax Environmental Markets Trust

The trust's objective is to enable investors to benefit from growth in the markets for cleaner and more efficient energy, water and waste services.

A £1million investment in the trust produced 340 megalitres of water treated or saved, which is equivalent to the waste water generated by about 2,700 UK households, according to Impax's latest annual report.

The trust, which celebrated its 15th birthday in February, also recovered or treated 79 tonnes of materials per £1 million invested - the equivalent of the total waste produced by more than 80 UK households.

'It is worth mentioning that this trust is currently trading at a 10 per cent discount to its net asset value, reinforcing the attractiveness of such an investment,' Lardoux says.

The trust boasts a return of 63 per cent over the past five years.

Threadneedle UK Social Bond fund

The Threadneedle UK Social Bond fund aims to achieve a positive social impact by investing in listed bonds issued by organisations that support socially beneficial activities and balanced economic development - primarily in the UK. 

Key social themes include employment, education, social housing, transport and infrastructure.

The fund was launched in 2014 through a partnership with Big Issue Invest, the social investment arm of The Big Issue Group. 

More than 80 per cent of the fund's assets has been allocated to investments with a medium to high social impact, according to its most recent annual report.

'Also, using a “Jobs Assessment Methodology” shows that 83 per cent of the assets are concentrated in sectors with a good jobs performance and 87 per cent of the assets are in sectors that have a relatively high employment concentration in the most deprived areas of the UK,' Lardoux says.

The fund has returned 24 per cent over the past five years. 

Bonds  

At the beginning of the month, impact investing company Lendahand Ethex launched a bond that bankrolls the supply of solar energy in homes in Africa.

Called Energise Africa, the bond hopes to whet investor appetite with returns of up to 6 per cent each year. Investors can deposit a minimum of £50 in different projects and can choose the location and term of their investment over two to three years. 

The idea here is the company will install solar home systems in African households and will recoup the cost over a one to two-year period. The homeowner will own the system once they complete the course of payments. 

The product can also be held in the tax-efficient innovative finance Isa through the online platform Lendahand.co.uk.

Investments in the bond aren't protected by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS), which covers investors in regulated products up to £50,000 in the case of an investment company going bust. 

Meanwhile, the more recent bond by renewable energy firm Monnow Valley Biomass takes a different tack.

It seeks to raise money to go towards refinancing the installation of two new biomass systems at a goat farm in Monmouthshire, supplying goats’ milk to companies including Waitrose.

Investing in a refinancing project is risky business, but the firm is attempting to woo investors by offering interest of 8 per cent.

This product is the epitome of long-term investing as the bond is due to mature after 19 years. In other words, investors wouldn't receive their initial investment back until 2036. However, there is a secondary market for investors sell the product on if they so choose.

It is available through ethical peer-to-peer finance platform Abundance Investment and can be held for in the Abundance innovative finance Isa - which means investors can earn tax-free returns.

As Abundance Investment is an authorised financial firm in the UK, investments made through the platform are protected by the FSCS safety net.

It is important to flag that both bonds are unsecured so all of your capital is at risk if you choose to invest. 

Ethical savings accounts

Ethics but what ethics?

Not all propositions classified as an ethical investment are the same, so it is important for investors to do their research before piling into one.

There are three main strategies that have stemmed from the concept of investing in a way that has a positive impact on the world. 

One of the most common forms of this is ethical investing - the practice of excluding controversial sectors such as tobacco and armaments as well as those involved in animal testing from consideration. 

Meanwhile, sustainable investing involves selecting companies for positive environmental, social and governance (ESG) initiatives.

So firms that reduce their carbon footprint and those with good corporate governance structure would make the cut. 

Crucially however, this strategy does not factor in the impact of the product or services.

Impact investing, on the other hand, goes a step further. This type of investing seeks out companies, organisations, and funds with the intention to generate social and environmental impact through their products, services and business practices.

For those who have no appetite in taking a risk and investing their money, there are a number of ethical savings accounts available.

These are relatively risk-free as savings in UK banks, building societies and credit unions are protected by the FSCS. However, the trade off here is lower returns compared to what you could achieve by investing.

It is difficult to compare ethical savings account because one could offer an attractive headline savings rate but aren't actually as ethical as they claim.

Here, individuals would have to decide what is more important: the return or the ethics.

The best known names in the ethical savings account space are Ecology Building Society, Charity Bank and Triodos Bank.

The three institutions rank one, two and three respectively on ethical finance research firm Ethical Consumer's guide to ethical savings accounts.

Ecology Building Society has stopped issuing its cash Isa that pays out 1 per cent in interest to new customers as a temporary measure because of high levels of demand.

Meanwhile, the Charity Bank equivalent pays 0.96 per cent but requires a minimum opening deposit of £250 and a 33 days notice period, whereas Triodos Bank's pays 0.75 per cent with a minimum opening deposit of £10.

item.title: Don't give your online banking details to new mobile phone budgeting apps, warns NatWest
item.description: Banks are warning customers not to hand over confidential details to mobile phone apps aimed at savers' budgeting.
item.content:encoded:
Banks are warning customers not to hand over confidential details to mobile phone apps aimed at savers' budgeting.

These apps typically link to your bank account to analyse spending habits to see how much you can save each month.

But most of these apps — including Chip, Cleo, Moneybox, Money Dashboard, OnTrees and Plum — ask customers for full log-in details for online banking.

One NatWest customer contacted Money Mail after being asked to hand over her username and password. 

The official NatWest online banking site only asks for a random selection of these digits.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Revealed: Best current accounts for added travel, mobile and breakdown cover. But are they worth paying for?

When the bank was informed, it issued a stern warning to customers not to give this type of information to apps. 

An RBS spokesman says: 'We do not authorise the use of these apps.' Halifax, Lloyds and Nationwide BS also confirm customers will break security agreements by giving out details. 

It means they may struggle to get a refund if their details then fall into the hands of fraudsters, experts warn.

But HSBC is planning to launch its own budgeting app next year to allow customers to view all their accounts in one place — including those from other banks.

Barclays says it is fine for customers to share these details with 'reputable' apps, while Santander will allow them to do so from January 13. 

From then, new EU rules mean banks will have to change their terms to let customers use this kind of budgeting app.

The Financial Data and Technology Association, which represents money app providers, says: 'Our members have been providing aggregation services without incident for several years.'

item.title: The 10 expensive car parts you'll need to replace most over your lifetime of driving (at a cost of £30k)... and how to make them last longer
item.description: If you pass your driving test at 17 and continue driving until 80 you'll spend 63 years behind the wheel and need to replace some of these expensive consumables up to 25 times.
item.content:encoded:
Receiving a hefty car repair bill is never enjoyable, and it can be doubly painful when you see that your mechanic has fitted new parts that you've had replaced before.

If you pass your driving test at the age of 17 and continue driving until you're 80, you'll spend 63 years behind the wheel and need to replace some of these expensive consumables up to 25 times, a new study has revealed.

Based on the average lifespan and cost of these parts you will have to fork out approximately £30,287 to have these 10 components replaced throughout your motoring years, says ClickMechanic.

We reveal how to identify when these parts need replacing and ways of extending their life expectancy. (Although with a ban on new diesel and petrol cars from 2040, you might find things change substantially in your driving life.)

1. Fuel Filter

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 25 

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving: £1,775

Signs it needs replacing: 'Check Engine' warning light is illuminated on the dashboards, the engine feels rough, increased fuel consumption, car struggles to start.

How to extend the lifespan: The filter is there to prevent dirt entering the fuel pump, so it will clog up over time. You can make attempts to clean it, but it's best to replace it by the manufacturer's recommended schedule.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you find cheaper car insurance? Compare with our MoneySupermarket-powered search

2. Battery

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 13

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving:  £2,015

Signs it needs replacing: The car doesn't start, the electric don't work, a pale blue or white powder appears on parts of the battery.

How to extend the lifespan: A battery survives better in cool climates, which is good new for Britons. In warmer temperatures a battery can discharge. If you tend to use your car only for short trips, make sure you squeeze in the odd longer trek - this will help to replenish the battery and extend the lifecycle. Obviously, sapping the battery by leaving your lights on overnight is a surefire way of guaranteeing the battery will need replacing sooner rather than later. 

3. Flywheel

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 10

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving: £7,740

Signs it needs replacing: Slipping clutch, difficulty changing gear, unusual transmission noise when using the clutch - can be easily mistaken for a clutch problem.

How to extend the lifespan: Changing the flywheel is usually recommended when changing the clutch, as a faulty clutch can often damage the flywheel, which may then damage the new clutch if not replaced. 

To prolong the flywheel’s life, you need to prolong the clutch - you'll find out how to do that next...

4. Clutch

How are these figures calculated? 

The top ten car parts were taken from ClickMechanic’s own database of vehicle repairs. 

The number of times a part needs replacing is based on the average mileage of each part calculated with an average of 63 driving years for an individual and travelling an average distance of 7,800 miles per year, which is taken from Gov.uk’s 2016 National Travel Survey.

Nationwide costs for the parts are taken from ClickMechanic’s quote engine and are based on a small city car.

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 10

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving:  £5,670 

Signs it needs replacing: clutch slipping, difficulty changing fear, noise from the transmission when using the clutch.

How to extend the lifespan: The lifespan of a clutch should be fairly long, however continually incorrect use over time will see it perish more rapidly. 

Use the clutch as little as possible. For instance, when at a standstill at a set of traffic lights put the car into neutral and apply the handbrake instead of feathering the clutch with the vehicle in gear. 

Make sure gear changes are smooth and rapid and move your left foot away from the clutch pedal when you're not using it to prevent accidental application. 

5. Front Brake Pads/Discs

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 10 

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving: £1,730

Signs it needs replacing: Takes longer to slow down with the brakes applied, squeaking or grinding when the brakes are on, brake warning light on dashboard, vibration and car pulling to one side under braking, grooves or cracks in the surface of the brake disc.

How to extend the lifespan: Don't brake so harshly and they'll last longer. Where possible, have both sides of pads and discs replaced together (either front or back) to make sure they're balanced.

6. Alternator 

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 7

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving: £2,506

Signs it needs replacing: Dim dashboard/interior lights, battery warning light, flat battery.

How to extend the lifespan: Most electrical factors will affect the lifespan of the alternator, from starting the car to using the air conditioning. Unfortunately, there is little you can do to extend its life - just try to stick to the replacement intervals set by the manufacturer. 

7. Cambelt/Timing Belt

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 6

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving:  £2,088

Signs it needs replacing: A grinding or high-pitch screeching noise from the engine bay, the car not starting.

How to extend the lifespan: If the cambelt breaks, it can be a costly affair as it can lead to severe engine damage, especially if it whips around the engine bay. It should be replaced in accordance with the car manufacturer's recommended schedule. 

One way to ensure it makes it the specific servicing intervals is to store the car in a garage to regulate the temperature. Changes in conditions can make the rubber expand and contract, ageing it in the process. Keeping it indoors will delay this process. 

8. Water Pump

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 6

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving:  £1,608

Signs it needs replacing: Fluid leaked around the water pump, the car not starting, high engine temperature and overheating, an engine temperature warning light is on.

How to extend the lifespan: Make sure you change the coolant when recommended and the engine is topped up with oil. The replacement tends to take place at the same time as the cambelt or timing belt.

9. Cylinder Head Gasket

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 5

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving: £3,500

Signs it needs replacing: 'Check Engine' warning light is illuminated, the engine feels underpowered, smoke from the engine bay, engine temperature reading is high, coolant or oil around the cylinder head gasket, engine rattle.

How to extend the lifespan: It's all about preventing the gasket from overheating, which can lead to a 'blown head gasket'. To stop the engine temperature soaring, keeping the water pump in check is a must.  

10. Starter Motor

Approximate number of times your cars may need a new one: 5

Approximate cost over a lifetime of driving: £1,655

Signs it needs replacing: The engine doesn't start, there's excessive noise or a ticking sound when trying to start the engine.

How to extend the lifespan: Starter motors are particularly prone to wear and one of those components that is difficult to extend the life of. If you own an older car with a key ignition start rather than a push button, don't hold the key in the starting position for too long as this will unnecessarily cut the lifespan of the motor.

item.title: Can you trust the bonds that pay 8.5%? We run the rule over five deals wooing savers with juicy rates
item.description: These bonds promise rates of up to 8.5 per cent, compared to just 2.4 per cent with a top five-year deal. They may seem irresistible for retired savers worried about rising living costs.
item.content:encoded:
Savers are being tempted by deals offering triple the returns you get with the best fixed savings accounts.

These bonds promise rates of up to 8.5 per cent, compared to just 2.4 per cent with a top five-year deal. They may seem irresistible for retired savers worried about rising living costs.

Earlier this month, Money Mail revealed record low interest rates mean pensioners are getting half the income they would have got before the financial crisis ten years ago.

But Justin Modray, of Candid Financial Advice, says of the deals: ‘Ask why these companies offer such high returns — usually as the opportunity they are offering is far riskier than an ordinary savings account.’

Here, we run the rule over five deals wooing savers with juicy rates . . .

Blackmore bond — 8.5 per cent

The Blackmore Bond is run by an investment company that manages money in shares, residential property and renewable energy.

It uses investors’ money to buy properties, before doing them up and selling them at a profit. It also buys land in areas ripe for development — such as in Stratford, East London, near the Crossrail links.

The first bond launched last October and its second issue opened at the end of July. You have to invest a minimum of £5,000 and can’t access money for four years if you choose the 7.5 per cent option, or five for 8.5 per cent.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you find a better savings rate? Check our independent best buy tables

You get paid interest every three months, which is taxable.

However, the company plans to launch a new bond that can be placed in an Isa before Christmas.

THE RISKS: Your money is not covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS) or any official safety net if the company hits the rocks.

Blackmore offers its own scheme — the Capital Protection Scheme — which is backed by a third party and promises to cover any shortfall if the company goes bust.

Its first issue covered up to £75,000, but there is now no cap. A severe downturn in the property market could threaten your investment.

London Capital & Finance — 8 per cent 

London Capital & Finance lends money to small and medium-sized businesses that want to grow. To raise funds, it offers bonds that pay between 3.9 per cent and 8 per cent a year. The payouts come from interest LCF charges on its loans.

There are three options — a one-year bond paying 3.9 per cent, a two-year at 6.5 per cent and three-year paying 8 per cent. The minimum investment is £5,000 and you cannot access your money during the fixed period.

THE RISKS: LCF insists that companies put up property or other assets as security in case they can’t pay. However, you could take a hit if a company defaults.

LCF says it has repaid all interest and capital to investors since 2012. But the real test will be when there is a rate hike or downturn in the economy, when companies could struggle to repay debts.

Regenerate London Bond — 7 per cent

The Regenerate London Bond raises funds from savers to buy land and properties in areas such as London and the South East.

It applies for special planning permission to develop land and then sells it on at a profit to developers. Investors are paid 7 per cent a year, which is fixed for five years.

The minimum investment in the so-called mini-bond is £1,000 and you can only invest in multiples of £1,000 thereafter. You have until October 31 to invest.

THE RISKS: One drawback with this bond is that you can’t sell it, meaning you need to hold it until the end of the fixed period. And when it comes to mini-bonds, it is generally the case that the higher the rate on offer, the higher the risk.

The biggest danger is that the company you loan to fails and cannot repay its debt. Its only safety net is that bondholders have the first claim over assets if the company goes bust.

Could interest rates really rise soon? 

The Bank of England set the cat among the pigeons at its latest rate-setting meeting with words that some economists took to mean an interest rate rise could come as early as November.

Will this really happen? Can enough of the interest rate doves be won over to the side of the hawks? Has Mark Carney switched rate rise sides?

On this week's This is Money podcast we look at how likely a rise is soon - and whether it's now time to fix your mortgage. 

Press play to listen to this week's full episode below, or listen (and please subscribe you like the podcast) at iTunes, Acast and Audioboom or visit our This is Money Podcast page.

QuidCycle — 6.1 per cent

QuidCycle is a so-called peer-to-peer lending company, which brings together borrowers and savers.

Investors lend money to borrowers with expensive store and credit cards at lower interest rates than they are already paying.

There is just one bond available now, paying 6.1 per cent for five years. You must invest at least £500 and your money isn’t accessible until the fixed term expires.

THE RISKS: The worry is that the borrower won’t be able to make repayments. QuidCycle has a Provision Fund, a pot of money set aside in case borrowers can’t pay.

It claims to vet borrowers with a credit check and generally offer a borrower a loan with repayments at the same level or lower than they currently pay, so it’s affordable.

Your money is spread across at least five borrowers to limit your risk exposure, and there’s an option to lend a maximum of £100 to any single borrower.

Castle Trust Fortress — 2.7 per cent

This bond takes your money to fund mortgages. The repayments made by Castle Trust’s customers are used to pay you interest. 

There are four bonds to choose from — a one-year bond at 2.2 per cent, two years at 2.3 per cent, three years at 2.6 per cent and five years at 2.7 per cent. These offers close on Friday.

The minimum investment is £1,000 and you do not have access to your money in the fixed period.

You can opt for interest to be paid quarterly or on maturity. Money can also be put in a tax-free Isa.

THE RISKS: Your money is only as safe as Castle Trust. Like any regulated financial institution, it has funding to absorb bad debts. It says it has not lost money on any lending to date.

But if the property market struggles, it could hurt the business. The bonds are covered by the investment branch of the FSCS, so money is covered up to a maximum of £50,000.

item.title: Where the experts would invest £100,000: Spread your cash across multiple funds and consider keeping some back should an opportunity arise
item.description: 'Generating an income in retirement has never been harder, but that doesn't mean you should just give up', says Tom Becket, chief investment officer at Psigma Investment Management.
item.content:encoded:
If you're fortunate enough to have a pension pot of £100,000 you're now able to access but don't know what best to do with it, help is on hand.

With savings rates abysmal, we've asked some top investment professionals for their recommendations. 

Scroll down to read what they have to say. 

ONLY TAKE OUT THE TAX-FREE CASH...

...says Jeremy Greenwood, senior relationship manager at Seven Investment Management.

'Since tax-free money isn't easy to come by, my first step would be to take 25 per cent of the pension pot as a tax-free lump-sum.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Find out how much income you can expect in retirement by answering 7 simple questions

'But before you blow it on lottery tickets, remember you're more likely to die before you hit that jackpot.

Get help sorting your pension 

Pension freedom has delivered a lot more choice for people retiring today, but also some tough choices.

Should you buy an old-fashioned annuity, keep your pension invested in drawdown, or take lump sums of cash?

How do you balance investing to deliver the income you need with making sure your pot doesn't run out?

Good financial advice is essential when trying to work these things out, but finding it can be tricky.

This is Money has teamed up with Timber to offer readers easy access to carefully selected financial advisers who you can trust, with fair and affordable charges.

> Find out if Timber could help you

'So instead, I would transfer £20,000 into a stocks and shares Isa using up my annual allowance and put the money into a fund such as Ruffer Total Return, which has good long-term performance.

'I'd put £3,000 into NS&I Investment Guaranteed Growth Bonds and £2,000 into premium bonds for added peace of mind.

'For the remainder of the pot, I would choose lower risk funds with a track record for delivering income. I would opt for a fund that invests across the globe so I was not overly reliant on the fortunes of the UK stock market.

'I like Murray International, which has a 100-year track record, and Veritas Global Equity Income, which yields a decent 3.4 per cent.'

LEAVE THE POT ALONE TO GROW...

...says Gary Millward, a financial consultant at Alan Steel Asset Management.

'A £100,000 pension pot isn't much to live off unfortunately — even if you generate a yield of 4 per cent through your investments, that is only £4,000 a year.

'So I might try to grow the pot a bit more if I had the time to do so.

'I would choose funds that spread their money in different regions around the world, such as Rathbone Global Opportunities and Troy Trojan Income. 

'These both have quite a cautious approach and tend to focus on safer, "quality" companies. 

'To add some diversity into the mix, I also like River & Mercantile World Recovery, which focuses on out-of-favour companies that are set to recover in the future, and Invesco Perpetual Global Income, which backs businesses that grow their dividends year-on-year.'

TAKE CARE INVESTING IN HOUSES 

Landlords have had their income squeezed by a raft of tax hikes in recent years. But can you still make a decent return from investing in buy-to-let properties in retirement?

Experts say it could all depend on where in the country you choose to buy.

Stagnating house prices and political uncertainty has put an end to easy wins for ‘armchair landlords’.

But research suggests there are still good returns to be made in the North of England, where the rental market is strong but house prices remain relatively low.

Research by BM Solutions, Lloyds Bank’s buy-to-let lender, found the highest rental yield was in the North of England at 7 per cent, followed by 6.4 per cent in the North-West.

The lowest was in London at 4.4 per cent and 4.9 per cent in both the South East and South West.

Rental yield is the income you’ll get each year from rent as a percentage of the property purchase price. 

So if you bought a property for £150,000, a yield of 7 per cent would be equal to £10,500.

A study by Property Partner, a crowdfunding investing website, found the top ten towns for buy-to-let yields are all in the North of England, with Stoke-on-Trent topping the list, followed by Leeds, Gateshead and Newcastle.

TURN TO ASIA FOR AN INCOME BOOST...

...says Tom Becket, chief investment officer at Psigma Investment Management.

'Generating an income in retirement has never been harder, but that doesn't mean you should just give up and buy a crate of Tattinger and a Ferrari with your money.

'The key is not to put all of your eggs in one basket.

'I'd invest in Asia-focused funds, such as Prusik Asian Equity Income, where there is good growth potential for companies as well as decent dividends.

'I also like funds that focus on out-of-favour companies which could be on the brink of a turn-around, such as Artemis Global Income.

'I'd also have some money invested in gold, which can act as an insurance policy if there is economic uncertainty, as the precious metal tends to hold its value.

'And, finally, I would keep some money in cash partly as a buffer, but also to put to work quickly if an opportunity arises.'

SPREAD CASH IN A DOZEN FUNDS...

...says Jason Hollands, managing director at advisers Tilney Bestinvest.

'Spreading your money across a number of funds is key to reducing the risk you take and to protecting your pension pot — I would suggest at least 12.

'I would put half of the money into equity funds which invest in companies shares. These have the potential to grow your money further to replenish what you withdraw, and can also generate an income through the dividends companies pay out.

'My favoured income-generating UK funds include Evenlode Income, Unicorn UK Income and Threadneedle UK Equity Income.

'I would then put some money in a U.S.-focused fund such as Avvia Investors U.S. Equity Income and some in Europe through the Standard Life European Equity Income fund.

'I would put around 20 per cent of the pot into fixed income funds, which invest in corporate and government bonds, a further 15 per cent into property and the final portion into an Absolute Return fund which would aim to protect my money if the stock market took a tumble.'

BEWARE LOW RETURNS ON CASH FUNDS

Keeping a slice of your pension pot in cash in retirement can be a good idea if you intend to make regular withdrawals. But the rates on offer are usually awful — some draw-down providers pay nothing at all.

However, if you shop around you can find up to 0.35  per cent.

Experts say it’s common for savers to keep around 5 per cent to 10 per cent of their pot in cash.

This enables you to access your cash if you intend to draw an income in the next year or two. It also means you have some funds that are not at risk through investing.

Research by financial website Boring Money found Fidelity offers 0.35 per cent and Aviva pays 0.25 per cent.

By comparison, Charles Stanley Direct offers 0 per cent , as does AJ Bell Youinvest on balances below £50,000.

Holly Mackay, founder of Boring Money, says investors should not choose their pension fund based on cash rates as the returns on their long-term investments are more important.

‘Cash rates are typically low on draw-down products because the money is supposed to be invested,’ she says. ‘It is not a factor I would suggest people focus on when choosing a provider.’

SEEK PERSONAL TIPS FROM A PRO...

...says Ian Browne, pension expert at Old Mutual Wealth.

'I would spend some of the money getting financial advice. A professional financial planner can help to assess what you need in retirement impartially and devise a strategy to deliver it.

'Investing in retirement requires an entirely different attitude and approach than when you're investing to try to grow your pension pot.

'When you invest for the long-term, you can afford to take some risk because you have time to ride out any ups and downs in the stock market. But when you're in retirement you need to focus on preserving your cash and minimising these ups and downs.

'For those investors who prefer the DIY approach, a multi-asset fund could be a good option. These are a type of one-stop shop where the fund manager has the freedom to pick which assets he thinks will perform best, such as bond, company shares, property and gold.

'Among the top performing multi-asset options are Premier Multi-Asset Global Growth and F&C Multi-Manager Investment Trust.'

item.title: Half a million cars will NOT need an MOT next year under new rules that will see 40 year-old vehicles exempt for the roadworthiness test
item.description: An additional 300,000 cars in Britain will no longer need an MOT test from next year under new rules that will see any model older than 40 years exempt from the annual roadworthiness check-up.
item.content:encoded:
An additional 300,000 cars driven on British roads will no longer need an MOT test from next year under new rules that will see any model older than 40 years exempt from the annual roadworthiness check-up.

Currently, only vehicles built or first registered before 1960 are exempt from the MOT test - accounting for almost 200,000 cars in use today.

The Department for Transport confirmed on Friday that it will loosen the restriction from next year with a rolling scheme that will mean any car more than four decades old won't need an MOT certificate.

The new rule means owners of cars built over 40 years ago will not have to book their car in at a garage for the test - which costs up to £54.85 - from May 2018, the government announced.

The DfT estimates that it will mean an additional 293,000 UK cars and motorcycles will no longer need to have the mechanical examination every year under the rule change. 

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you find cheaper car insurance? Compare with our MoneySupermarket-powered search

At the moment, around 197,000 pre-1960 vehicles registered on UK roads are exempt from the annual check-up. 

When this change takes places next year it will mean approximately 1.5 per cent of the total 31.7million cars currently being used on British roads will be MOT-exempt.

With almost half a million cars now qualifying to be legally driven without an MOT certificate, fears will grow that many older vehicles on the road may be dangerous.

This was the verdict of those questioned as part of the Government consultation on the changes held earlier this year. 

Ahead of the decision, more than 2,000 members of the public took part in the dialogue to abolish the test for cars older than 40 years.

Of those quizzed, 56 per cent opposed the plans, with many voicing concerns that vehicles travelling on public roads should have an annual check-up for safety reasons.

In contrast, 899 respondents supported the changes to the rules.

In response to concerns around safety the DfT said cars more than 40 years old are often kept in good condition by owners, and not used regularly enough to warrant an MOT. 

The department added that the test is also no longer relevant to cars that were built more than 40 years ago, making it almost impossible for testing centres to pass them.

The consultation also proposed a more basic biennial test for models that fell out of the 40 year bracket, which would include checking the vehicle identity and making sure important components - like the brakes - were in working order.

However, the DfT decided not to go ahead with the introduction of the check-up, stating : 'Those owners who feel an annual check is needed will be able to submit their vehicles for a voluntary MOT.'

Parliamentary under secretary of state, Jesse Norman MP, said: 'After considering the responses, we have decided to exempt most vehicles over 40 years-old from the requirement for annual roadworthiness testing. 

'This means lighter vehicles (such as cars and motorcycles) and those larger vehicles such as buses which are not used commercially. 

'Heavy Goods Vehicles and Public Service Vehicles falling under operator licensing regulations will remain within the scope of roadworthiness testing. 

'This will ensure a proportionate approach to testing for older vehicles, which works for public safety and vehicle owners.'

Earlier this week, an independent investigation found that British car owners have been hit with nearly half a million fines totalling £35million for not having a valid MOT certificate in the last five years.

The Treasury has been raking in MOT penalty revenue at the rate of around £7.5million a year, it said.

Critics say the MOT test – which takes its name from the initials of the old Ministry of Transport - is now becoming the government's latest revenue-raising 'cash cow' by ministers who could solve the issue overnight by sending out simple paper reminders.

item.title: Best car scrappage schemes in 2018: Which car brands are still offering discounts on new models when you trade in your old banger?
item.description: Many car makers have extended scrappage schemes into 2018. Dacia, Ford, Hyundai, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, PSA, Renault, Toyota and the VW Group all have trade-in offers.
item.content:encoded:
A scrappage scheme lets you trade in your old car and replace it with a more efficient new model with a hefty discount. 

While the government dragging its heels with a proposed diesel scrappage scheme, 26 car manufacturers took the decision into their own hands by offering discounts on new models when drivers trade-in older vehicles during 2017.

All the major players had a scheme of some description, including the VW Group - including Volkswagen, Audi, Seat and Skoda - BMW, Ford, Mercedes and Vauxhall.

Some of these offers have now expired, but 16 car makers have extended their offers into 2018 - find out which current deal is best and what the biggest discounts are when you hand over your ageing vehicle.

Scroll down for video 

Which car brands still have scrappage schemes?

Some 26 car brands offer scrappage schemes in 2017, however around half expired at the end of the year.

That leaves 16 manufacturers who have extended - or introduced - their offers into the new year, most of which run until the end of March. 

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Can you find cheaper car insurance? Compare with our MoneySupermarket-powered search

Are motorists using scrappage shemes?

Research by independent car buying site, carwow, revealed that motorists want a significant discount if they're to swap their old banger for a greener alternative.

More than 50 per cent of UK drivers said that they wouldn’t consider anything less than £3,000 compensation to consider a move towards cleaner vehicles, whilst one in six would be looking for a minimum of £7,000.

So how many drivers took advantage of schemes last year?  

At the end of June 2017, Vauxhall confirmed that over 5,000 drivers had utilised its deal after just two months. With similar schemes running in 2015 and 2016, the car maker - now owned by the PSA Group - said it had scrapped more than 20,000 old cars (and shifted 20,000 new ones) through the incentive.

Ford and Volkswagen, which have provided schemes since August and September 2017 respectively, claimed to have swapped more than 15,000 older vehicles for greener Euro6-compliant models by December.  

Can I trade-in my car?

Not every manufacturer-offered scrappage scheme is the same, as you're going to increasingly find in this article. That's not just true for the new models you could be buying but also the ones they're willing to take from you.

Most of the brands accept both petrol and diesel models, though the VW Group manufacturers (Audi, Seat, Skoda and Volkswagen) will only take diesel examples.

Almost all of the schemes are only applicable to cars registered before 2010.

Here's what the different car brands are happy to take:

Dacia: Any Euro 1-4 rated DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 December 2009

Ford: Any Euro 1-4 rated DIESEL or PETROL car or commercial vehicle registered before 31 December 2009

Hyundai: Any Euro 1-4 rated DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 December 2009

Kia: Any DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 March 2011

Mazda: Any Euro 1-4 rated DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 December 2009 

Mitsubishi: Any Euro 1-4 rated DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 December 2009

Nissan: Any Euro 1-4 rated DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 December 2009

PSA Group (Peugeot, Citroen and DS): Any DIESEL or PETROL car more than 7 years old

Renault: Any DIESEL or PETROL  car (subject to an appraisal of its road-worthy condition at a Renault participating dealer)  

Toyota: Any DIESEL or PETROL car registered before 31 December 2009

VW Group (Volkswagen, Audi, Seat, Skoda): Any Euro1-4 rated DIESEL car registered before 31 December 2009

What will happen to my old car? 

Dacia: all cars traded in will be 'responsibly scrapped'.

Ford: all cars and vans traded in will be scrapped.

Hyundai: all Euro 1, 2 and 3 cars traded in will be scrapped but Euro 4 models may be sold on.

Kia: all cars traded in will be scrapped.

Mazda: all cars traded in will be recycled by Cartakeback.com.

Mitsubishi: all cars traded in will be scrapped. 

Nissan: no confirmation.

PSA Group (Peugeot, Citroen, DS Automobiles): all cars traded in will be recycled by scrappage partner Cartakeback.com.

Renault: no confirmation.

Toyota: all trade-in cars will be recycled 'in the greenest possible way'.

VW Group (Audi, Seat, Skoda, Volkswagen): all cars traded in under the scheme will be scrapped.


What other trade-in restrictions do I face?

Again, not all the brands have the same restrictions beyond the fuel type and age of the car as listed above.

Some demand that you've owned the car for longer periods than others. For instance, Mitsubishi, Toyota and the VW Group brands say they will only deal with those who have been the registered keeper of the trade-in car for a minimum of 6 months.

Ford, Hyundai, Kia, Nissan Peugeot, and Renault  are more lenient, though - they only ask that motorists have kept their cars for 90 days to qualify for their offers. Mazda goes a month shorter, requiring just 60 days ownership ahead of ordering the new car. 

All the brands will accept cars made by other manufacturers. For instance, you still qualify for the Ford saving if you hand over an old BMW or Mercedes-Benz.

IS MY CAR ELIGIBLE FOR THE SCRAPPAGE DEALS OFFERED?
BRAND EMISSIONS RATING FUELLED BY... OWNED BY YOU FOR AT LEAST
DaciaAny Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009 Petrol or diesel90 days 
Ford Any Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009 Petrol or diesel 90 days
Kia Any car registered before 31 March 2011Petrol or diesel3 months
HyundaiAny Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009Petrol or diesel90 days
MazdaAny Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009Petrol or diesel 60 days
MitsubishiAny Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009Petrol or diesel6 months 
Nissan Any Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009Petrol or diesel90 days 
PSA Group (Peugeot, Citroen, DS)Any car more than 7 years oldPetrol or diesel90 days
Renault Any car (subject to a roadworthiness appraisal by the dealer)Petrol or diesel 90 days 
ToyotaAny Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009 Petrol or diesel 6 months 
VW Group (Volkswagen, Audi, Seat, Skoda) Any Euro1-4 rated car registered before 31 December 2009Diesel only6 months 

Which new models will I get a discount on - and how much could I save?

Yet again, there are plenty of inconsistencies. We've broken each brand down and given you a quick overview of what's available, though we suggest visiting each manufacturer's website to find out more if you're interested:

Dacia - offer on Sandero and Duster extended until 31 March 2018

Only the Sandero and Duster are eligible for the Dacia Scrappage Scheme. Why not the Logan MCV estate? We don't know.

The savings are pretty small - £2,000 off a Duster SUV and £500 clipped from the RRP of the Sandero supermini - but considering their low purchase prices in the first instance, the discounts are actually a good percentage of the overall cost. 

Ford - extended deal now expires on 31 March 2018

Ford is being generous with the range of petrol and diesel cars you can choose from, though they're all subject to different discounts (just to make it a little more confusing).

For instance, the scrappage saving when you want a new Fiesta is just £2,000, but you can save £4,950 on a high-spec Focus if you trade-in your Euro4-or-earlier motor.

Other models include the B-MAX (excluding Zetec, with a £3,500 saving), C-MAX (up to £4,700 saving), Kuga (up to £4,850 saving) and various Transit models with a maximum discount of £7,000. The new Ranger has also been added (up to £2,750 off the RRP). 

Hyundai - scrappage and emissions reduction scheme available until March 31

Hyundai's scrappage and emissions reduction scheme has varying discounts across the range, including models themselves. For instance, an i10 city car qualifies for a £1,500 saving, though if you go for the 1.0 SE model that offer increases to £1,750.

Other cars included are the i20 (up to £2,865 off), i30 (£4,000 off), i40 (£3,000 off), ix20 (£2,000 off), Tucson (£3,500 off) and seven-seat Santa Fe (£5,000 off).

Oddly, the car Hyundai should really be persuading drivers to purchase is the Ioniq range, which includes a conventional hybrid, plug-in hybrid and full electric version. However, only the the standard hybrid version is available in the offer and with a measly discount of £2,000 off the £21,000 saloon. 

Kia - incentive runs until the end of March 2018

The Korean car manufacturer is only discounting its smallest models - the Picanto and Rio. 

Both are eligible for a £2,000 saving. With that, you get the brand's market-leading seven-year warranty. 

Mazda - new car needs to be registered by 31 March 2018 to qualify 

Mazda's scheme is available on a select few models, though the restriction is that any new vehicle you buy has to emit less than 130g/km of CO2. The Japanese brand is also offering bigger discounts on models with diesel engines than those with petrols, seemingly in a push to clear stock of oil burners.

Models and savings: Mazda2 (petrol only with £2,500 discount), Mazda3 (petrol models offer a £4,000 discount and diesel £5,000), Mazda 6 (petrol models offer a £4,000 discount and diesel £5,000), CX-3 (diesel only with a £3,000 discount). 

Mitsubishi - offer expires on 27 March 2018

The model most buyers will be interested in is the Outlander PHEV - the country's best-selling hybrid car. The Japanese brand is offering a £4,000 scrappage allowance on the vehicle, which you can then combine with a £2,500 saving through the plug-in car grant to pocket £6,500 of the RRP. 

But there are other savings to be had too: £2,000 off a Mirage supermini, £3,000 off the ASX compact SUV and £5,000 off a diesel-powered Outlander 4x4. 

Nissan - 'Switch scheme' open until 2 April 2018

The Nissan 'Switch Scheme' is unlike any other scrappage offer featured here. Yes, you have to own an older diesel or petrol car for at least 90 days, but when you trade in you could get a discount on, wait for it, another used car. That's only the case for second-hand Nissan LEAFs which are elgible for 'up to' a £2,000 saving.

There are deals on new models, too, but only with a maximum £2,000 off the RRP of models including the Micra, Juke, Qashqai and X-Trail. Go for the Acenta trim level on any of these and that discount drops to just £1,000. 

PSA Group - save up to £6,000 on a new Peugeot, Citroen or DS until March

The French motor group is quick to point out that any discounts available here cannot be used in connection with any other deals and in some cases is knocking more off the price of diesel models than petrols in a bid to offset the decline in sales of oil burning cars. Luckily, some of the savings are pretty big. Here's what's available in 2018:

Peugeot: 108 (£1,750 off), 208 (£2,750 off), 2008 (£2,750 off), petrol 308 (£2,750 off), diesel 308 (£3,750 off), petrol 308 SW (£2,750 off), diesel 308 SW (£3,750 off), 308 GTi (£2,750 off), petrol 3008 (£2,000 off), diesel 3008 (£2,500 off), 508 (£6,000 off), 508 SW (£6,000 off) and Partner Teepee (£2,500 off).

Citroen: C1 (£1,750 off), C3 (£1,750 off), C3 Aircross (£1,700 off), C4 Cactus (£3,900 off), C3 Picasso (£6,400 off), C4 (£5,000 off), C4 Picasso (£4,200 off), Grand C4 Picasso (£4,700 off), Berlingo Multispace (£2,500 off).

DS: DS 3 (£3,500 off, DS 3 Cabrio (£4,500 off), DS 4 (£5,000 off), DS 4 Crossback (£5,000 off), DS 5 (£5,500 off).

Like Ford, Peugeot and Citroen also has a range of vans with discounts of up to £7,000 + VAT off the Peugeot Boxer Van and Citroen Relay Panel Van.

Renault - Upgrade Event expires on 31 March 2018

Renault's traditional scrappage scheme ended in December, but the French car maker has launched a new 'Upgrade' package on part-exchanged cars - though only if you want to buy one of the three SUVs it sells.

On the plus side, any car can be traded in, as long as Renault deem it to be of a roadworthy condition. The part-exchange value will be boosted by varying amounts depending on which model you choose.

Go for a petrol-powered Captur and Renault will add £250 to the value of your trade-in car - choose the diesel-powered compact SUV and that will increase to £500.

The bigger Kadjar is subject to a part-ex boost of £500 and £1,500 on new petrol and diesel models respectively, while anyone who chooses the new Koleos will get £2,000 added to their trade-in vehicle value. 

Toyota - Scrappage also extended to end of March

The Japanese car manufacturer has included pretty much its entire model range, from the Aygo city car to the Hilux truck.

Discounts vary depending on which model you want, with the smallest being £1,000 off the C-HR and C-HR Hybrid SUVs. The most substantial saving is £4,000 off a new Land Cruiser 4x4.

Making up the entire availability range is the following: Aygo (£2,000 off), Yaris and Yaris Hybrid (£2,500 off), Auris and Auris Hybrid (£3,500 off), Verso (£3,500 off), Rav4 and RAV4 Hybrid (£3,500 off), Avensis (£3,500 off), Prius (£2,000 off), GT86 (£2,000 off), Hilux (£2,000 off) and Proace (£2,000 off).

Toyota's deal was due to expire at the end of January but has now been extended to 31 March 2018.

VW Group - Audi, Seat, Skoda and Volkswagen schemes extended until 31 March 2018

With Volkswagen, Audi, Seat and Skoda models all inclusive of the VW Group's scheme, there is a wide range of models up for grabs. These range from £1,500 off the dinky Seat Mii and Skoda CitiGo to an £8,000 discount on an Audi Q7 e-tron SUV.

Volkswagen's latest line-up of plug-in hybrids is also inclusive of the offer, with cars like the hybrid Golf GTE (£5,000 off) and pure-electric e-Golf (£5,500 off) up for grabs. 

The all-new Polo has also been added to the scheme from mid November, with £2,000 off when you trade-in your old diesel car. 

The biggest issue with this offer is that it is only applicable to those with older diesel cars - anyone with a pre-2010 petrol will have to consider one of the alternative incentives. 

Volkswagen said some 5,000 pre-Euro5 diesel cars had been swapped for more efficient new cars since its incentive was offered.

Drivers will have to order a new VW, Audi, Seat or Skoda model by the end of March and have it delivered by 30 June if they want to take advantage of the scrappage discounts offered. 

WHICH MODELS FROM EACH BRAND ARE ELIGIBLE FOR A DISCOUNT?
BRAND DEAL OFFERED CARS THAT QUALIFY

Citroen £1,750 - £7,000 discount on new model C1,  C3, C3 Aircross, C4 Cactus, C3 Picasso, C4, C4 Picasso, Grand C4 Picasso, Berlingo Multispace, Nemo Panel Van, Berlingo Panel Van, Dispatch Panel Van, Relay Panel Van

Dacia£500 - £2,000 discount on new modelSandero, Duster

Kia£2,000 discount on new modelPicanto, Rio

Toyota£1,000 - £5,000 discount on new model Aygo, Yaris and Yaris Hybrid, Auris and Auris Hybrid, Verso, RAV4 and RAV4 Hybrid, C-HR and C-HR Hybrid, Avensis, Prius, GT86, Land Cruiser, Hilux, Proacre 
Volkswagen£1,800 - £6,000 discount on new model up!, old and new Polo, Golf, Golf SV, Touran, Tiguan, Beetle, Jetta, Scirocco, Passat, Arteon, Sharan, Golf GTE PHEV, Passat GTE PHEV, e-up! EV, e-Golf EV

Which one is the best value scrappage scheme? 

Renault's offer isn't a traditional scrappage scheme and provides the lowest financial appeal. The restriction to just SUVs will also alienate some buyers.

The French carmaker's sister brand, Dacia, is also low on our recommended list as it only offers relatively small discounts on two cars in the range - the Sandero and Duster - and you have to have owned the trade-in vehicle for a minimum of 90 days. That said, a £500 off the price of a car that costs just £6,000 new isn't a bad deal at all. 

Kia's deal is similar in that it is limited to just its small cars, though the £2,000 saving on a Picanto or Rio is good value considering their lower list prices. 

Toyota's offer is competitive, though the savings aren't as tempting as some rivals and there is a requirement of a minimum 6 month ownership of the vehicle you trade in.

Mazda's offer provides substantial savings on some good cars but is cannily providing bigger discounts on diesel examples than petrol to shift vehicles that have fallen out of favour with buyers in recent months.

The VW Group's scheme - including Volkswagen, Audi, Seat and Skoda cars - hands out some of the biggest discounts at the moment, though it has the restriction of only being available to those with an old diesel car to trade-in.

We highly rate the Mitsubishi scrappage scheme - you can trade-in an old petrol or diesel car and pocket big savings on the popular Outlander PHEV. The only reason it misses out on featuring in our 'best offer' group is because the trade-in ownership period is longer than the better schemes - 6 months - and the deal expires marginally earlier (March 27) than most of the others.

The Hyundai scrappage and emissions reduction scheme provides some good savings on models across its range, especially the large popular SUVs like the Tucson and Santa Fe, but we're hugely disappointed that they're only offering £2,000 off the price of the Ioniq Hybrid and the plug-in hybrid and full electric models aren't inclusive of a scheme that's meant to encourage drivers to go green. 

Nissan was one of our recommended schemes, but the extension of their offer has seen a reduction in the discounts provided. Now all models are subject to a maximum of £2,000 off, which isn't as good as the best deals. 

The better options are from Ford and PSA Group (Peugeot, Citroen and DS). Not only will they take an older diesel OR petrol car as part of the scrappage deal, you can get the most substantial discounts on some of their popular cars - like the Ford Focus, Citroen C4 Picasso and Peugeot 308  - and not be restricted to only being able to buy diesel. All also only require you to have kept the trade-in model for 90 days.

How to get a good deal on car scrappage

In this excerpt from the weekly This is Money podcast, Simon Lambert, Rob Hull and Georgie Frost take a look at car scrappage schemes and how you can squeeze the best deal out of them.

Press play to listen to the scrappage tips below, or listen (and please subscribe if you like the podcast) at iTunes, Acast and Audioboom or visit our This is Money Podcast page.

Does this mean the government won't be launching a scheme?

Government ministers are said to be consulting on the scheme in a bid to remove as many older diesel cars from the road, but Michael Gove, Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, has said it's not the ideal option - possibly because it would cost the government a significant amount of money (the last one in 2009 reportedly cost £300 million).

Instead, it is calling on councils to make a more concerted effort to reduce emissions at 81 major roads it has identified that are breaching EU air quality standards.

If a government scrappage scheme does arrive, expect it be targeted to only the oldest diesel models, which may or may not include Euro 4 cars.

Does the discount apply to the retail price of a new car or the price I can negotiate? 

No, all offers are on top of any discount you can already haggle on one of the eligible vehicles. However, some of the brands - including Peugeot and the VW Group makes - specifically state that the scrappage offers cannot be used in conjunction with any other existing offers. Check the manufacturer websites to find out more.
item.dc:abstract: Many car brands have scrappage schemes that have been extended into 2018. Dacia, Ford, Hyundai, Kia, Mazda, Mitsubishi, Nissan, PSA Group, Renault, Toyota and the VW Group all have trade-in offers available, mostly until the end of March. Each deal offers discounts on new models when you trade-in your old car. Almost all of the existing incentives are willing to take any vehicle registered before 2010, though the VW Group is the only one that will accept just diesel cars. Which scheme is the best one? Find out which one we recommend in our in-depth scrappage scheme guide.
