item.title: Travelling with Flybe for a city break? Make sure you don't get stung by the baggage catch like LEE BOYCE
item.description: On a recent trip to Budapest via Southend booked with Flybe, I was caught out by its smaller baggage allowance - why couldn't staff have just been more understanding?
item.content:encoded:
I love a weekend city break, whether it is hopping in the car and going on a British adventure, or making a short flight to Europe on a budget carrier.

We're lucky in Britain – we have numerous airlines willing to cart us around to the different cultural experiences of Europe, most of which are within a few hours' reach, usually for a reasonable price.

I have flown with Easyjet and Ryanair more times than I can remember, and on the whole, have found the pair to be efficient and good value for money. 

I just treat them as a bus in a sky - no bells, whistles, or red carpet treatment expected. 

Recently, there was exciting news as Flybe announced it was to launch a number of new destinations from (London!) Southend Airport – which is just a 10 minute ride away by train from home for me and a far less painful experience than the juggernauts some airports have morphed into.

It has opened the door to a number of interesting destinations including Budapest, the city spot I chose to visit to celebrate my 30th birthday with my partner.

Ahead of the trip, flying out on a Saturday in late May and returning on Tuesday, we were contacted twice by Flybe.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Get more for your holiday money: The best debit and credit cards to beat overseas fees

First of all, we were informed that the time of the return flight was changing to far later in the day on Tuesday, meaning we had to amend plans.

Secondly, we were told that the return aircraft wouldn't be operated by Flybe, but instead by Jota Aviation. Both of these points made us worry that a third e-mail would be sent saying the flight was pulled.

When the morning arrived and waiting to jet off to the Hungarian capital, we were hovering around duty free at Southend when the dreaded red letters flashed up on the screen saying that it was our 'final call' for the Budapest flight.

This despite a few moments earlier saying 'waiting for information'.

We raced over to the gate (it's only a small airport) along with others to find the staff had accidentally put that sign up – and that actually, the flight was running late.

Eventually, the queue formed and that's when I saw it – the dreaded metal measuring device they use for checking luggage you take on board. 

Frankly, it looked like you couldn't get a briefcase, or even a ferret, inside let alone a travel bag for a long weekend. 

I rarely pay extra to put luggage in the hold on short-haul as I hate waiting at the other end for it - and it takes vital time out of your trip.

My bag is one of those that is meant to fit on board the budget airlines and I have taken it as hand luggage on many trips via Easyjet and Ryanair.

SIZE MATTERS

Flybe changed its bag dimensions in April last year. These subtle changes have no doubt caught many out. 

Prior to April 2016, you were permitted to bring a single cabin bag measuring no more than 55x40x23cm - this changed to 55x35x20cm (including wheels and handles).

This is compared to 56x45x25cm on Easyjet and 55x40x20cm on Ryanair (which also allows an additional smaller bag on). 

Easyjet are less generous on this front (top tip - if you do have a handbag, make sure you buy a 5p duty free carrier bag from duty free and put it inside).

Flybe: 55x35x20cm

Easyjet: 56x45x25cm (16cm more generous)

Jet2:  56x 45x25cm (16cm more generous)

Ryanair: 55x40x20cm (5cm more generous)

Thousands of others are likely to have bought a similar-sized bag in recent years precisely for this purpose.

I had been rushing around the night before and hadn't checked the dimensions for Flybe hand luggage, which I soon discovered, is less generous than its rivals. 

I accept that I should have checked - after all, I spend my life trawling terms and conditions here at This is Money – but it's what happened next that irked me.

Worried travellers were comically trying to stuff their bags into the device and many couldn't get them in. 

I tried mine and it wasn't going to fit without a hacksaw. I explained, but Flybe staff were having none of it.

I, along with a handful of others, seem to have been picked on and charged for oversized luggage.

Others, whose bags also didn't appear to fit, weren't charged.

My argument was you either charge everyone - or nobody at all. 

I also explained that the bag fits on other rivals airlines, that it was an honest mistake and I would pay its normal price for hold luggage - but staff weren't having any of it. 

Eventually, I stumped up the cash - £40 – despite the unjust attitude of the staff who I just couldn't reason with. 

By that point I wanted to board and enjoy my birthday celebrations rather than continue to get annoyed by a stealth charge over a few centimetres of bag.

They didn't tell me that the £40 didn't cover the return flight – or any details as to how I could avoid the problem a few days later. 

When we did board, not only was our return flight via Jota, but the outbound was too - and there was plenty of space on the aircraft.

We had a marvellous weekend in Budapest; it's a real mix of ruin bars, beautiful architecture, hot baths and history. But on the last day, I had that sense of dread about my bag.

I tried to check-in online via its app on my Android smartphone to see if I needed to book my bag on – but annoyingly, the app just wouldn't work.

Not wanting to ruin our final day of the trip, I gave up. At the airport, I tried to explain, but to no avail. 

I had to run across Budapest airport, find the baggage counter, part with another £40 (with currency charges more like £50) and queue once again at the check-in desk. 

An extremely frustrating experience.

Recent research from Columbus Direct shows that we stump up an estimated £395million a year at airports for overweight and excess baggage.

One in five have paid a charge in the last two years, on average, at £135 a pop - so I am not alone.

The insurer said: 'The variation and complexity of luggage allowances between different carriers based on the permitted number of bags, weight and dimensions helps explain why so many Britons are caught out by excess charges.'

I never thought I'd get stung this way – and the attitude of staff have left me questioning whether I can be bothered to give Flybe another go.

For short-haul, I'm inclined to stick with Easyjet and Ryanair. 

Exeter-based Flybe lost £20million in the year to the end of March. It flew 8.8million passengers in the year to the end of March, despite growing its capacity to accommodate 12.7million.

I asked Flybe:

- Why was I picked to have my bag charged, when it appeared other passengers with bags that didn't fit weren't charged? Is it company policy to pick and choose random bags that are too big?

- Does your app work for Android customers? And would I have been able to add a bag for the return leg if it did work properly?

- Are staff incentivised to charge extra for baggage?

- How many passengers end up having to pay for extra luggage with Flybe? How much does it make the firm each year?

The Flybe press office deflected my query. It said: 'With regard to your enquiry regarding the flight operated by Jota Aviation on behalf of Stobart Air, can I ask that you direct your enquiries to the Stobart team at Southend Airport'.

It means I've paid Flybe to go with Stobart Air who use Jota Aviation planes. A complicated three-way partnership.

A spokesman for Jota Aviation, or Stobart Air, or Southend Airport – I'm not sure which – disputes my claim that many with oversized bags were allowed on.

They said: 'The new sized gauges were introduced recently by the airline and we are obliged to follow their guidance on the sizing and charging of bags.

'Having spoken to the staff at the gate they are adamant that they charged for the bags that were oversized, this is supported by the fact that there were a number of bags charged for on this specific flight.

'There may be some confusion where some bags are observed to not be checked at the gate, this is because any passengers that go to check-in will have their hand luggage checked there and it is tagged at that point, that ensures that we are not checking the same bag twice.

BEEN CAUGHT OUT?

Have you had to pay for excess luggage on a recent flight? 

Let us know your experience in the comments below... 

'The issue of the booked load does not come in to this as the passenger has a contract with the airline specific to themselves and their hand luggage.

'If handlers were asked to make decisions on the amount of hand luggage allowed defined by the booked load there would be few flights departing on time.

'In relation to the charge being one way only the passenger's point has been taken on board and the staff have been asked to ensure this is advised.' 

My advice is this: if you are someone that flies from Southend Airport regularly and are used to the hand luggage sizes of Easyjet, get your ruler out if you're going with Flybe - or just accept that you need to pay to put your luggage in the hold.

item.title: Don't get stuck in the inheritance tax maze: We answer the questions you must ask to pass on as much as possible
item.description: Inheritance is an area of personal finance that can get very complicated, very quickly and what might seem relatively straightforward at first glance, often isn’t.
item.content:encoded:
Over the past few years more and more people have sought to reduce the inheritance tax their loved ones will pay on their death - but with so many changes, it's getting harder.

Inheritance is an area of personal finance that can get very complicated, very quickly and what might seem relatively straightforward at first glance, often isn’t.

Worse, getting it wrong could have a big impact on the amount of money your family actually receives when you die.

The first step in thinking about inheritance is to work out the extent your wealth goes over any allowances.

Once you have an idea of how much inheritance tax your family might have to pay, you can think about steps to reduce the potential bill. 

These fall into three categories: insuring, gifting and investing.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Find out about getting help with will writing and lasting power of attorney

Another critical step in getting this right is writing it down: if you think you don’t need to make a will, think again. This is the easiest way to make sure your family isn’t left with a financial headache after your death.

We've put together a Q&A to help you get started, with help from Jeannie Boyle, a chartered financial planner. 

How much IHT will I have to pay?

This is quite easy. Write down how much everything you own is worth (don’t include pensions in this) and take away how much money you owe. 

This is called your estate and it is the amount that your IHT bill is based on. 

You do get tax free allowances, but anything you leave over these thresholds will be taxed at 40 per cent.

My biggest asset is my home. Can I just give it to the kids and live there?

Most of the time this won’t work. If you give something away, but can still ‘enjoy’ it then it isn’t really a gift. So, living rent free would cause problems.

However, if you paid rent at a commercial rate this could be a solution. You would need to get a solicitor involved to ensure that there was a clear written agreement. As well as reducing the potential for family conflict, it prevents HMRC taking issue with your arrangements – they aren’t keen on arrangements involving the family home.

If you ran out of money to pay rent you could be evicted and may find claiming state benefits difficult if you are deemed to have ‘deliberately deprived’ yourself of money. If you died within seven years there may be IHT to pay on the gift and the residence nil rate band (RNRB) cannot be used against this. (More on this later).

Will my partner get everything?

If you haven’t made a will your partner won’t inherit any of your assets unless you are married or in a civil partnership. This is true regardless of how long you have been living together or whether you have children together. There is no such thing as a common law spouse.

The laws of intestacy (when you die without a will) determine what happens to your wealth. 

If you are unmarried your assets will go to your children, grandchildren, parents, siblings, nieces and nephews. If you have no living family your estate passes to the Crown.

If your partner was financially dependent on you they would have to make a claim for financial hardship under the Inheritance Act, but this make take some time to process and they still may not receive all your assets.

Even if you make a will leaving everything to your partner, they will still have to pay IHT on anything over the value of £325,000. Only assets left to spouses or civil partners are exempt from inheritance tax. Getting married for tax purposes might not be romantic, but it can make financial sense.

I’m married, so my spouse will inherit everything – do I still need a will?

Many people assume everything they own will pass to their spouse, but if your personal assets are worth more than £250,000 this isn’t the case. 

Any assets you own jointly will automatically go to your spouse (most couples own their home as joint tenants). 

Your spouse also keeps all the assets and personal possessions up to a value of £250,000. If you don’t have any children, your spouse also keeps everything else. 

If you have children, your spouse and the children get half each of everything over £250,000 – your spouse gets 50 per cent and the kids share the other 50 per cent. 

Remember that only your spouse can inherit free of inheritance tax – if the children receive more than £325,000, then someone will have to pay some inheritance tax.

If you make a will you can make sure your wishes are carried out – it can also help avoid any family squabbling about who gets what.

How much can I leave free of tax?

The nil rate band is the amount everyone can leave without any inheritance tax. 

Currently it’s £325,000 but married couples can double their allowances up to leave up to £650,000 free of IHT. 

The nil rate band has been frozen since 2009/10 – one of the reasons so many more people are paying IHT. 

It is due to start increasing with inflation from 2020/21.

But thanks to an new - and slightly complicated - releif for your home if you own it, you can now leave more.

I thought I could leave £1million?

This was the Conservative Government’s manifesto promise, but what the former Chancellor George Osborne actually delivered was quite different. 

The new residential nil rate band (RNRB) came into effect in April this year. 

It applies to a residential property that you have lived in at some point in your life and own when you die and leave to your child or grandchild. Adopted and step children can also benefit from this allowance.

The RNRB is being phased in starting at £100,000 this year, then increasing every tax year until it reaches £175,000 in 2020/21. 

Like the standard nil rate band, it can be passed to a surviving spouse. This applies even if your spouse died before the new allowance was introduced.

For a detailed look at these changes, read more here. 

IHT above £2m 

Once the full main home extra allowance is in place, the taper means that it will be lost altogether for estates worth above £2.7million.

The Government didn’t want to be seen introducing a benefit for the very wealthy so there is taper in place. If your total estate is valued at more than £2million, then £1 of the RNRB will be removed for every £2 over the £2million threshold.

So by 2020/21 a married couple would be able to leave £1million of assets free of inheritance tax, but only if they have children AND they have a residential property worth at least £350,000 AND if their total taxable estate was no more than £2million.

I have savings, but no property – can I use the new allowance?

If you sold a residential property in order to downsize or move into a care home you can use the RNRB against the value you realised from the sale of your primary residence.

To qualify, the property must have been sold on or after 8 July 2015 and the cash must be passed to your children or grandchildren.

If you’ve never owned your own home then you can’t use the RNRB, even if your other assets are worth more than the standard NRB. 

Likewise, if your home is worth less than the RNRB you can’t switch the unused allowance to other assets. So if you have decided to live in a modest property and saved hard all your life, you are out of luck.

What about my pension?

In most circumstances, your pension fund is exempt from inheritance tax. If you die before age 75 your loved ones will not pay any tax on the fund. 

If you are over 75 when you pass away, your beneficiaries will pay income tax (at 0 per cent, 20 per cent, 40 per cent or 45 per cent, depending on their own income tax rate).

If you have other savings and investments it makes sense to use these to provide your income in retirement instead of your pension. This means the taxable assets are reduced but the non-taxable asset – the pension – retains its value and can be passed on free of IHT.

There is an exception to this rule. If you move your pension from one provider to another whilst you are in poor health and then die within two years HMRC can include the value of the pension is your taxable estate. 

It’s best to speak to a financial adviser about these issues.

Is there anything else that is exempt from inheritance tax?

If you run your own business or own shares in a business these could be exempt from inheritance tax. 

Shares in qualifying unlisted businesses qualify for 100 per cent business property relief (BPR) provided they are held at death and for two of the preceding five years.

Some types of business don’t qualify, even if they are unlisted. Typically, anything to do with investment or property will be excluded.

There are also exemptions for agricultural land and woodlands. It’s best to speak to an adviser to make sure your holdings will be exempt.

What about giving to charity in my will? 

Gifts to charity or political parties are exempt from inheritance tax. 

You can also benefit from a reduction in the rate of tax paid from 40 per cent to 36 per cent by leaving 10 per cent of your net estate to charity. This only applies to gifts made through your will.

If you were thinking about gifting 4 per cent of your estate to charity, you would increase the amount left to your other beneficiaries by increasing your gift to 10 per cent.

Can I insure against inheritance tax?

The people administering your estate have to pay any IHT that is due before they can sell or pass on any assets. 

A whole of life insurance policy provides an immediate sum of money on death to help with this. The sum assured is usually equivalent to the expected inheritance tax liability on your estate, and is paid into a trust to ensure it is not included in your taxable estate.

 Government doesn’t allow you to simply give everything away at the last moment to avoid tax

The drawback to these policies is that they can be very expensive. In some cases the premiums can increase dramatically after five or ten years. If you cancel the policy before you die you will not benefit.

The premiums themselves can be paid as gifts out of regular income. If you have other life assurance policies it’s a good idea to have their proceeds paid into a trust as well, to ensure there is no IHT on the value.

You should only do this if you’re in good health, otherwise there could be a transfer of value for IHT purposes.

Can I give away my money?

Yes you can – but the type of gift you are making will determine how it is treated for IHT. 

The Government doesn’t allow you to simply give everything away at the last moment to avoid tax. In most instances you need to live for seven years after making a gift to ensure it is free of IHT. It will really help your executors if you keep clear records of the gifts you have made.

Gifting early means there is more chance you will survive seven years and get the benefit of seeing your loved ones enjoy the wealth you have created.

If you have assets that you think might grow in value, it can make sense to give these away instead of cash as all the growth will be outside of your estate immediately. 

Remember that you may have to pay capital gains tax if you give away an asset which has grown in value since you purchased it. 

Capital gains tax at 10 per cent or 20 per cent on the profit might be better value than 40 per cent IHT on the whole gift.

For a gift to be effective for IHT purposes it must be made without any strings attached. If you continue to use a gift you have ‘reserved the benefit’.

I have more income than I spend, can I give this away?

If you have more money than you need and you have money saved for the future, it doesn’t make sense to keep accumulating savings that will be taxed after your death. Gifts made out of surplus income are exempt from IHT. 

To be eligible your gift needs to be made habitually (this doesn’t necessarily mean every month or year). It also needs to be part of your normal expenditure leaving you with enough income to keep up your normal standard of living. Gifts could be made to help a loved one with education fees or mortgage repayments.

GIFT ALLOWANCES 

There are several allowances for gifts which are automatically exempt from IHT:

· Every year you can gift £3,000. This allowance can be carried forward one tax year if unused

· You can make unlimited small gifts of £250

· Gifts between spouses or for the maintenance of children, ex-spouses or dependent relatives are exempt

· Gifts to people getting married are also exempt; up to £5,000 for your child, £2,500 for your grandchild or great-grandchild, and £1,000 for anyone else

Can I give my grandchildren some money?

An outright gift of capital is called a potentially exempt transfer. The gift is potentially exempt because, providing you live seven years after making the gift, then there is no IHT to pay. 

However, if you die within seven years the recipient may have to pay IHT and the gift will use up part or all of your nil rate band.

The amount of tax charged is tapered over seven years. Lots of people think it’s the value of the gift that reduces, which is incorrect. This is important because a large gift – over £325,000 – will mean you have no nil rate band available until the seven year period ends so all your other assets could be subject to IHT.

It’s also important to remember the person who received the gift will have to pay the tax. You can take out an insurance policy to provide the recipient with the money to pay the tax, but this can be expensive.

Can I ensure grandchildren don't get access to the money too early?

It’s not always appropriate to make an outright gift to an individual, especially if they are under 18. Setting up a trust allows you to start the seven year clock ticking without giving immediate access to large sums of money.

 Setting up a discretionary trust gives the trustees (which can include you) flexibility over who should benefit and when they can access the money

The simplest form of trust is a bare trust or absolute trust. Setting up a bare trust for a minor gives them the assets for tax purposes, but the trustees retain control until the child reaches 18. 

One potential drawback is that the child can demand full access once they turn 18 - quite an alarming prospect.

Setting up a discretionary trust gives the trustees (which can include you) flexibility over who should benefit and when they can access the money. 

This allows you to provide for family members – including those not yet born – in line with your wishes, and to protect family wealth being spent irresponsibly or becoming subject to divorce proceedings. 

As the name suggests the trustees have discretion over who among the range of possible beneficiaries receives a benefit and when they receive it. 

As there is no immediately identifiable taxable beneficiary, HMRC requires such trusts to be assessed for IHT every 10 years to avoid families holding wealth outside of the IHT net. 

Currently the maximum rate of IHT such trusts need to pay every 10 years is 6 per cent. You should never set up such a trust without first seeking professional guidance.

If your gift to a discretionary trust is more than £325,000 there can be an immediate tax charge. There can also be tax charges every 10 years. It’s best to speak to a financial planner or legal adviser before setting up this type of trust to ensure it meets your needs.

What if I think I might need the money back?

Giving money to a trust is the same as giving money to an individual – you have no right to ask for it back. You need to be sure you won’t need the capital in the future. 

An alternative solution is a gift and loan trust. You set up a trust by making a small gift – usually £10 – then loan the trustees some money to invest. The trustees then invest the money – the growth on the investment is outside your estate, but you can ask for your loan to be repaid at any time.

This doesn’t achieve a huge saving in inheritance tax on day one, but you have the security of knowing you can get your money back. It also means you still have your nil rate band available for other gifts.

What investments are free of IHT?

Shares in qualifying, unlisted business qualify for 100 per cent business property relief provided they are held at the date of death and for two of the preceding five years. This means there is no IHT to pay on their value.

Qualifying investments quoted on the Alternative Investment Market qualify for BPR and can also be held within a tax-free Isa.

Investing in AIM companies carries a higher level of risk than larger companies listed on the main stock exchange: your investment could fail entirely, resulting in a far greater loss than any potential IHT liability. 

In addition, not all AIM companies qualify for BPR. It can be helpful to use an AIM portfolio management service to ensure the right stocks are purchased and the risk is spread across a number of holdings.

The Enterprise Investment Scheme was set up to encourage investment in small private companies that might otherwise struggle to raise capital. 

Investors benefit from a range of tax reliefs including up to 30 per cent upfront income tax relief, and full IHT relief after a two year holding period.

Where do I go to get help?

If you are unsure what the best course of action for your circumstances is, speak to a financial adviser. 

Chartered financial planners have a high level of qualification so should be equipped to deal with most estate planning needs. For complicated situations seek out a STEP qualified planner. 

Drawing up will or setting up a trust may require input from a solicitor.

HMRC has published a guide to the new RNRB including 18 case studies showing how the new band will and will not help in certain circumstances.

Jeannie Boyle, is executive director and a chartered financial planner at EQ Investors

item.title: Debt collectors keep sending demands to my flat to the previous tenant - will it affect my credit score?
item.description: I've received several letters from debt collectors and I'm worried it's going to leave a mark on my credit history, even though they're not in my name.
item.content:encoded:
During the past few months I've received several debt collection letters to my flat but in someone else's name.

They're addressed to the previous tenant but I don't have a forwarding address for her and I'm worried this may be affecting my credit score.

I'm also concerned if the debt collectors can't get hold of the tenant they may send a bailiff to my home. 

Is there any chance the previous tenant is using my addresses to obtain credit and could this have an effect on my credit score? Via email.

Rebecca Rutt, of This is Money, replies: Whenever you apply for any type of credit, be it for a new credit card, a loan, a mobile phone contract or even a mortgage, your credit score will be checked by the lender.

This is done so it can make a decision over whether to approve the credit to you and at what rate of interest so therefore it's important you regularly check your own.

You say you've been receiving letters from debt collection agencies and that although they are not in your name, they are under your address.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • How to improve and protect your credit rating and check your credit report

You are now worried that as the previous tenant is being chased by debt collectors, your own credit score could be affected or you may even get a visit from a bailiff at the door.

We approached an expert to see where you stand.

James Jones, head of consumer affairs at Experian, replies: 'As far as your credit rating is concerned, unless the previous tenant is using your name then your rating should be totally safe. 

'This is because credit checks these days take place on people and not on addresses. People can only be linked on credit checks by joint financial activity, such as if two people take out a joint loan or joint bank account. That's unlikely to have happened here.

'Most people who are linked in this way will be current or ex-partners. If you want to double check this, simply order a copy of your credit report from any of the three credit reference agencies (Experian, Equifax and Callcredit) and check the section called 'financial associations'. 

'If the previous tenant's name is not there then you have absolutely nothing to worry about.

'On to those debt demands. I suggest you return any post sent to the previous tenant straight back to the senders, making it very clear they no longer live at the address. They should eventually get the message. If they persist, get the head office address of the firm or firms in question and send a formal, written complaint.

'Your own credit report should include details of any credit accounts (such as cards, bank accounts, loans, mail order accounts, car finance, and mobile phone contracts) that you've used in the last six years. 

'These records will show whether you made the monthly payments on time and, for open accounts, how much you currently owe. Other records added to credit reports include court judgments and insolvencies, the electoral roll, and a record of any recent credit applications.

'It's sensible to review your credit report with all three credit reference agencies at least once a year and, additionally, before making any important credit application. 

'That way, if you spot a discrepancy you can ask the agency to correct it before it affects you. A one-off 'statutory' report costs just £2 and you can sometimes get this for free.'

Rebecca Rutt adds: 'Even if you don't have a forwarding address for the tenant, you can send back these letters to the companies in question.

As the debt isn't in your name, the firms involved should stop sending these letters but if you're concerned about a bailiff turning up at your door you can always seek advice from a charity such as Citizens Advice. 

It has conducted a lot of work around debt collection agency practices during the past year. In circumstances where a bailiff is involved, an advanced notice is sent out at least seven days before they are allowed to visit a property. However, as the debt isn't in your name, this is extremely unlikely to happen.

FIVE TIPS TO IMPROVE YOUR CREDIT SCORE

There are a number of ways you can improve your credit score, here are five quick tips and our guide has full details.

1. Get into the habit of using credit on a regular basis, but never take on more than you can afford.

2. Always stay within the agreed credit limits and make your repayments on time.

3. Don't apply for lots of credit in one go, these will leave a mark on your credit score and can be seen as a sign of financial stress.

4. Register to vote at your current address as lenders use the electoral register to help confirm who you are and where you live.

5. Regularly review your credit report to make sure everything is accurate and there are no unexplained transactions or applications.

item.title: I have a good job for a tech firm but work on a zero hours contract, can I get a mortgage?
item.description: This works well for me as I like the flexibility, but the problem is my bank doesn’t seem interested – they’ll only give me a mortgage based on half my income.
item.content:encoded:
I have been working for a tech firm for the past 18 months but don’t have a full time contract. 

I am employed – like everyone who works there – on a zero hour contract. This works well for me as I like the flexibility, but I have been saving a deposit and now want to apply for a mortgage. 

The problem is my bank doesn’t seem interested – they’ll only give me a mortgage based on half my income. 

This doesn’t seem fair – are there any other options for me?

Sarah Davidson of This is Money says: A zero hour contract is one under which an employee is not guaranteed work. For employees, zero hour contracts can work around existing commitments and enable people to take up the option of doing more hours when available, as suits them.

Employers have a staff resource which can be called on when the need arises, giving flexibility and peace of mind that they have a trained and capable workforce for busy periods. 

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Compare rates and get independent mortgage advice from across the whole market

They’ve recognised the benefits of such contracts, leading to a massive 460 per cent increase over 10 years.

However they are controversial because while they suit some workers, others struggle with a lack of job security and benefits they would otherwise be entitled to as employees.  

David Shelton, senior underwriter at Ipswich Building Society, replies: Rest assured you are not alone in this problem - there are a growing number of people who are on zero hour contracts. 

The ONS Labour Force Survey reports 0.5 per cent of people (147,000) in employment in October to December 2006 were on a zero hour contract, compared to 2.8 per cent of people (905,000) in the same period of 2016. 

Of these, 22 per cent are in the accommodation and food sector and 20 per cent are employed in health and social work.

Interestingly, 46 per cent of people on zero hour contracts (412,000) have been with their employer for two years and over, compared to 38 per cent (309,000) at the same period in the previous year – and of people in employment on a zero hour contract, 34 per cent (308,000) are on a full time basis.

Although these people may consider themselves able to fulfil a financial commitment such as a mortgage, and be able to prove a regular income, not all mortgage lenders will take this into account. 

Some mortgage providers use a computer based scoring system to assess mortgage applicants and affordability. 

Automated processes are not always able to take into account circumstances such as multiple sources of income, older borrowers and those who are self-employed or on zero hour contracts. 

The mortgage industry is increasingly using the term ‘misfit’ to refer to these people who may find themselves locked out of the mortgage market.

With this in mind it can feel that some organisations do not want to help - but there are providers out there which take a very different approach and will work with you to understand your personal circumstances. 

Organisations such as this will use trained underwriters to make individual lending decisions. Typically, underwriters will use a range of items to make a decision. You should be prepared to provide information such as:

In summary, shop around, and seek out a mortgage provider who is prepared to assess your mortgage application on its individual merits. This is known as manual underwriting.

Sarah Davidson of This is Money, adds: The smaller building societies are particularly good at taking a common sense approach to assessing whether or not you can reasonably afford to take on a mortgage. 

The information you provide to them might take a bit more organisation on your part, but it's usually worth it.

A lot of the smaller ones, including Market Harborough, Ipswich, Newcastle, Melton Mowbray, Saffron, Leek, Rugby & Hinckley, Marsden, Cambridge and Furness offer very competitive rates as well.

You might have time to approach a few yourself, but going to a mortgage broker who deals with several could be a quick win for you. 

The advantage of using a broker is that they will also have access to specialist lenders which don't offer mortgages directly to customers - only through mortgage advisers. 

Many of these are completely focused on helping borrowers with slightly quirky or more flexible income characteristics. Some of the bigger ones which are notorious for helping the self-employed include Kensington Mortgages, The Mortgage Lender, Precise Mortgages, Aldermore and One Savings Bank.

There are lots of mortgage brokers who specialise in helping self-employed and contract workers so you shouldn't find it impossible to find a good deal.

item.title: I got a brand new 12-sided £1 coin in my change but it's dated 2016: Is it really worth hundreds of pounds?
item.description: Earlier in the week, I received a new £1 coin in my change. Upon closer inspection, the date on the coin is 2016 - is it worth far more than face value?
item.content:encoded:
Earlier in the week, I received a new 12-sided £1 coin in my change. Upon closer inspection, the year on the back of the coin is 2016.

I thought the coin only came out recently, so would have a 2017 date? A friend has told me that 2016 dated coins are in fact 'rare' and can fetch hundreds of pounds online.

Have I been lucky and found a valuable coin in my change? N.K, via e-mail.

Lee Boyce, This is Money consumer affairs editor, replies: The short answer to this question is no. But you're not the first to ask.

My dad, partner and two friends have all asked me all this very same question this week about the 2016 £1 coin – they have received them in their change and heard they are worth way more than face value.

HOW THIS IS MONEY CAN HELP

  • Why that 2p could be worth £1,400: The valuable coins that can turn up in your change

I have no idea where this myth started. It reminds me of the query we had about Benjamin Britten 50p coins last year which for one reason or another people believed to be rare and thus collectible. They're not. 

I visited the Royal Mint earlier in the year. At the time, I was told around half a billion £1 coins would have 2016 on them as they began production last year, in order to have enough coins ready for the 28 March launch.

Poll

The annual Isa allowance is now £20,000. If you had a £20k windfall, what would you do?

  • Blow it on a holiday or car 165 votes
  • Give it to charity 48 votes
  • Put it in your pension 149 votes
  • Pay off any debts 268 votes
  • Invest it in an Isa 377 votes
  • Use it for kids' education 52 votes

Now share your opinion

  •  
  •  
  •  
  •  
How much do you need to save for retirement? Use our pension calculator

The new 12-sided coins, which are made from two different coloured metals and have a hologram underneath the Queen's effigy, have been designed to combat fraud. Many of the old style round £1 coins are fakes.

The £1 coins listed on online marketplaces such as eBay are likely to be posted by chancers hoping to suck people into believing they are collectible.

Half a billion £1 coins with 2016 dates would mean roughly eight for every Briton, making them plentiful.

In contrast, the Kew Gardens 50p, which genuinely can fetch upwards of £50 online, had a mintage of just 210,000.

The Royal Mint will strike a total of 1.5billion of the £1 coins by the end of 2017. 

The only way a new £1 may have some sort of additional value is if there is a mistake on the coin. Don't be fooled - your £1 is very likely to be worth £1. 

For coins that can turn up in your change worth more than face value, check out this guide.

item.title: The hype surrounding some of these new app-only banks is deafening - but are they really going to take over the world of banking as we know it?
item.description: Richard Browning has seen banks come and go since the 1980s. The newest ones exist only on the home screen on your phone. Is that a good place for a bank? Here's his review of Monzo
item.content:encoded:
There'll always be a lot of excited talk about start-ups when companies such as Snap, behind the picture sharing app, is valued of tens of billions of dollars based on guessed future profits.

But Snapchat is popular, edging towards 200million users at the last count.

The trouble is, most tech start-ups aren’t popular and most don’t stand a chance.

Many simply drown in their own gibberish before they start. I’ve sat in pitches where inventors claim to be sitting on the greatest disruptive technology ever thought of but can’t explain what it is.

Fintech — or financial tech — start-ups, have a slightly better outlook.

Thanks to the almost total global financial collapse in the late noughties caused by banks and bankers, there is a tantalising Snapchat-sized jackpot for anyone who can create a new type of bank.

Imagine, say, a bank that provides customers with an experience that doesn’t involve queuing for your entire lunchtime to talk to a crook in a suit, whose job is to up-sell pointless payment protection insurance (PPI) and give to you it anyway when you refuse.

Imagine no more.

In the last few months the likes of Starling, Atom and Monzo have been snorting up banking licences like there is a tomorrow after all, to make banks that exist nowhere else but on the phone in your pocket.

They’ve even managed to create a buzz about financial products. The thing is, they’re all, well, rather too buzzy, or in English, gimmicky.

Don’t get me wrong, banks have always used gimmicks to attract customers. I got an Our Price record token when I opened an account with the Midland in the 1980s.

The youngsters ('millennials') building the new app-only banks won’t understand that previous sentence but they’re still dishing out gimmicks like they just thought of it —crowdfunding, community ideas forums, animated gifs to share with mates, oh and drone footage of the cool new offices, where ‘awesome meet ups’ will be hosted.

People used to hate gimmicks [savers don't want free dog biscuits]. Millennials, apparently, love them. 

I maybe old enough to remember when we got our first colour TV in the 1970s but I’m still young enough, thankfully, to remember how exciting it was to view a world previously only available in black, white and mostly grey.

When the internet first came along, that same excitement beamed down all over again. It was as magical as trying to understand email for the first time was baffling.

I feel sorry for millennials. It’s all always been there.

Email’s only ever been a chore, Facebook‘s a bore and Twitter’s where you scrawl what you once etched into the school desk and toilet cubicle wall. [Hat tip, Doc Brown]. Snapchat is the benchmark. It’s all they’ve got.

But recently colleagues and about-town millennials have been getting genuinely excited about a new technology. Not, say, Tesla, the exciting battery-power sports car, or the latest GoPro cameras you wear on your head when you jump out of planes and space shuttles – but a bank! 

Young people are getting excited about a bank. This I had to try.

I’d tried First Direct, the phone-up bank, when it launched nearly 30 years ago and I’m still with it. Its call centres are still pretty good even if it doesn’t offer much else in the way of attractive accounts.

I’d tried one of the wacky new internet-only banks, Egg, when it launched in the 90s. That lot kindly added PPI after I’d told them not to before they went on to get fined for mis-selling PPI and quietly vanishing into the banking footnotes of Wikipedia.

I also tried the recent, exciting challenger bank, Metro.

Metro’s a mystery to me.

It was great for a while — then it limited its worldwide fee-free cash withdrawals to Europe presumably once it remembered it was a bank and needed to make money.

But its website was terrible — a kind of free off-the-shelf DIY affair you wouldn’t bother paying for when the trial came to an end.

And that slogan, ‘No stupid bank rules’ — subverted by its own stupid rule of only locating branches on prominent street corners with enough space in front of the counter for a nightclub dancefloor or five-a-side football pitch.

That seems like one hell of an expensive gimmick in a world where people apparently no longer want branches. Or do they? Let's find out. 

The Monzo hype makes it sound like its the answer to everyone's banking prayers. 

Its aim is no less than: ‘Our deep understanding of product, technology and regulation enables us to build a financial control centre for everyone in the world.’ 

For now it’s just a pre-paid debit card.

I downloaded the Monzo app to see what it was like.

What happened when I signed up to the trendy new bank, where the only branch is an app on my phone?

 Week 1

Monzo says there aren’t enough debit cards to go round so I'll have to wait an unspecified length of time to get one UNLESS… I invite friends to sign up in which case I could get a card straight away.

They don’t have enough cards. But they do have enough cards. Which one is it? Bank trick number one?

I decide not to lure anyone else into this and wait. About a week later I’m granted access.

Week 2, Thursday

Unlike any other bank I’ve joined, it feels like a leap into the unknown.

The big fear is what happens to my money when I send it to an icon on my phone that could disappear as quickly as it downloaded.

To get started you need to send £100 to app land.

The app invites me to scan a debit card from another of my bank accounts — one I’m already perfectly happy with — to send cash to this one. It feels a bit pointless.

The trade-off is Monzo’s free cash withdrawals throughout the world.

Everyone should pay the same official Visa or Mastercard exchange rate when using cards abroad. But most providers add at least a couple of per cent as a fee on top. Some have other fixed fees on top of that. Monzo doesn’t. That's amazing. But remember, Metro didn’t to start with. Bank trick number two?

As instructed, I hold my debit card up to a window on my phone, which scans it. I tap in the expiry date and the three-digit security code.

The app tells me I have sent £100 but need to ‘enable notifications’. Then the app freezes. Has my hundred quid arrived or not? I mess about in the phone settings and change notifications manually. I go back to the app to check if the transfer has been as success. It doesn’t say.

Instead, it urges me to send an animation of a debit card sitting in a boat to my friends. I don’t have any friends who want one of those.

The page it wants me to share to friends on social media has my home address clearly displayed on it. Does Monzo really want me to post my address to Twitter and Facebook? I’m confused. I realise I'm already on the ‘activate card page’.

And the way to find out if my money has arrived is by activating my card. But I can’t activate a card I applied for a few minutes ago. It will arrive in the post on Saturday. I close the app and reopen it.

This time I’m greeted with another animated debit card. This one appears to be running away — with my hundred quid? Not pleased. The idea of sending large sums of money to app banks would be terrifying.

Week 2, Saturday

The bright orange card arrives in the post as promised. I don’t need to be in to sign for it, which is a bonus.

Given that the app has encouraged me to share Lord only knows what with the internet, it comes with a peculiar bold warning in the envelope: do not post your card number online.

Does Monzo think its customers are morons? It will go far as a proper bank after all. The rest of the process is easy and works first go. I activate the card and am reunited with my missing 100 pounds.

I make some test purchases. 

I buy a smoothie in Waitrose to see what millennial feels like and offset it with a sausage roll from a stand across the road because I’m Northern.

The purchases are logged and immediately categorised. The smoothie is classed as grocery and the sausage roll as eating out. I like that. You also get a little map to remind you exactly where you bought it in case you’d had eight pints before buying a smoothie, I mean sausage roll.

Overall my experiences with the card and app have been excellent. But is it for me?

The good stuff

No money went missing. The transfer arrived safely even though I was left in limbo for a couple of days.  When you spend money you see what you’ve spent immediately in the app with a little map of where you were geographically. I like maps.

The chatline people answer questions quickly. Spending is categorised so you can see how much you’re flitting away on needless snacks.

You can’t go overdrawn. I tried.

You can freeze the card immediately if you lose it or it’s stolen and want to prevent a thief from running up contactless payments — then unfreeze it when you find it in your other pocket.

When you spend abroad you see immediately the foreign spending converted into sterling with the exchange rate you're likely to get.

It’s good in theory for sticking within a tight budget. But it’s so easy to top up again from your other account that I’m not sure that stands up.

Fans say it's great for sending money to each other for sharing bills and the like. 

The not so good

I went to Morrisons the supermarket and the card was refused – some shops have different technology, I was told by the chatline people. That’s fine – the product is still in development, but if I load up my card for a foreign trip and it doesn’t work while I‘m away then its game over.

The ‘buzz’ it has created among fans is incomprehensible to me. There’s a forum for fans to help Monzo create the perfect bank. Customers are tweeting about how exciting the app is. Is this really as exciting as first getting colour TV and the internet?

No, it's not.

The Monzo mission is to build ‘a financial control centre for everyone in the world’. Wow!

The hubris behind the marketing is overwhelming and frankly detracts, possibly deliberately, from the fact that it is a bank. And banks end up greedy and corrupt.

Oh yeah, it isn’t really a bank. Not yet. It’s a pre-paid debit card with some impressive nobs on.

It doesn’t appear to have a business plan to recoup the millions of pounds of investment without becoming everything in banking it’s striving not to be.

What happens when it turns into a lender that hits customers with charges and its fans start to use the forums and social media to tear it to shreds remains to be seen.

It’s very good at what it does now. There is a real danger that as it adds more features in a bid to ‘improve’ it will complicate the app to the point of destruction. It’s a start-up. It’s what they do.

Is it for me?

Not yet. It was fun to try and I’ll check it out when it’s a bank.

I’m sick of banks. I’m sick of having a different card for this and one for that and savings accounts all over the place.

One bank that fits all would be amazing but might prove too good to be true.

I hope all this enthusiasm creates what it is hoping to become.

But ultimately it will always be the bank that sent me a video of a drone flying around its new empty office with space to host awesome meetups because someone thought that would appeal to me.

And that’s a worry.
